With a vibrant downtown and plentiful nearby outdoor recreation, Bozeman’s recent swanky transformation led to the Wall Street Journal dubbing the city “Boz Angeles.”  Bridger Bowl and Big Sky Resort, two major ski destinations, are within an hour of campus, while Yellowstone National Park is 90 miles away. About 60% of MSU graduates accepted jobs in Montana immediately after graduation.
carnegieClassification: Doctoral Universities: Very High Research Activity

name: University of Massachusetts Boston
description: Located in the Dorchester neighborhood, the University of Massachusetts, Boston is the only public research university in Boston. UMass Boston’s campus is three miles from downtown, tucked away on the waterfront next to the John F. Kennedy Library and Presidential Museum. The 220,000-square-foot Integrated Sciences Complex features numerous science research laboratories, including an infant cognition lab and the Center for Personalized Cancer Therapy. UMass Boston opened the doors to its first-ever residence hall, which cost $120 million and has more than 1,000 beds, in 2018. Notable UMass Boston alumni include former ​​New York City Police Commissioner William Bratton and fashion designer Joseph Abboud.

name: University of Redlands
description: The University of Redlands in Redlands, CA, is a private liberal arts school that aims to give students a personalized, unique college experience. The university offers around 40 programs for undergraduates, and many students at Redlands study business. During “May Term,” students can take courses outside of the normal curriculum either on campus or abroad. Students are required to engage in community service learning. Students and faculty volunteer 100,000 hours of service to nonprofits and partner organizations each year. There are more than 100 student clubs on campus, including Greek life chapters that date back to the beginning of the school’s history. About 94% of students found employment, enrolled in graduate school or pursued service within one year of graduating. Redlands has produced 24 Fulbright scholars, including three recipients in 2019.

name: University of Texas, El Paso
description: The University of Texas at El Paso is a comprehensive research university that enrolls a high percentage of Hispanic students. Undergraduates can choose from over 70 degree programs. Popular programs include business, engineering and the health professions. About 43% of students take part in research or a scholarly project before they graduate. UTEP boasts more than $100 million in annual research expenditures and is ranked fifth in the state for federal research expenditures at a public university. Students take part in 1 million hours of community service annually, as well as more than 200 clubs, Greek life and Division I athletics. UTEP is one of the largest Hispanic-Serving Institutions in the country, with Hispanic students making up over 80% of the student body. Almost half of students are first-generation.
carnegieClassification: Doctoral Universities: Very High Research Activity

name: University of Idaho
description: The University of Idaho in Moscow, ID, is a land-grant university with a research-driven and innovative culture. Undergraduates can choose from over 90 degree programs, as well as pre-professional tracks in a number of health sciences fields. Popular majors include psychology, mechanical engineering and marketing. The university also offers programs at four other locations in Idaho, including Boise. U of I has ​​over $113.1 million in research expenditures annually. Undergraduates are encouraged to take part in research, and about 75% do so. Almost a quarter of the student body participates in Greek life. With more than 200 clubs and an Outdoor Program that offers rentals and trips, there is plenty to do outside of the classroom. The Idaho Vandals compete at the NCAA Division I level. Idaho students are eligible for merit scholarships ranging from $1,000 to $4,000, and the Vandal Promise program provides additional scholarship and grant support that enables low-income Idaho residents attend.​​ U of I is part of the Western Undergraduate Exchange program, which allows students from select states to attend for reduced out-of-state tuition.

name: Saint Peter's University
description: Located in the heart of Jersey City, Saint Peter’s University is New Jersey’s only Jesuit university. Undergraduates can choose from over 50 majors, as well as pre-professional programs with the New Jersey Institute of Technology, Rutgers University, Seton Hall University and the University of Medicine and Dentistry of New Jersey. Popular majors include biology, business and criminal justice. Saint Peter’s also offers classes in New York City, utilizing its close proximity to provide students with robust job and internship opportunities. In line with its Jesuit values, the university runs a number of community service projects that over 700 students take part in annually. Campus ministry runs a robust retreat program to encourage spiritual discovery. Saint Peter’s is a Hispanic-serving institution, with almost half of the student body identifying as such. The majority of students hail from New Jersey, and about half are Pell Grant recipients.

name: Regis University
description: Regis University is a private Jesuit Catholic school in Denver, CO, with a reputation for educating veterans. The university’s main campus is in Northwest Denver, but Regis also operates campuses in nearby Thornton, CO, and Greenwood Village, CO. Regis is one of the most veteran-friendly colleges in the country, with 15% of the student body identifying as a veteran, active duty military or military reserve. The Center for the Study of War Experience further solidifies Regis’ connection with veterans, conducting oral history interviews with those involved in military conflict. Some 91% of Regis graduates reported employment within six months of graduation, with the most common employment areas being healthcare, education and government.

name: Southwestern University
description: The first institution of higher education in Texas, Southwestern University in Georgetown is a small, private university with an interdisciplinary liberal arts curriculum. Students can choose from over 30 majors. Popular programs include business, psychology, biology and political science. SU is one of only a handful of undergraduate liberal arts universities that support a separate school of fine arts. The intimate community is bustling, with over 90 student organizations, including Greek life. SU, just 30 minutes from Austin, has faculty-led programs in countries like Buenos Aires, Amsterdam and London, as well as study-away study and internship options in New York and Washington, D.C. The Brown Scholarship is Southwestern’s most prestigious and competitive award and is valued at $35,000 per year. General merit scholarships range up to $28,500 annually.  Approximately 61% of the Class of 2020 is employed—the majority of which remained in Texas—and 24% are pursuing advanced degrees.

name: Mercer University
description: Mercer University in Macon, GA is a private university that encourages research and service through the liberal arts and pre-professional development. Mercer offers more than 130 academic programs in 12 degree-granting schools and colleges, including 14 pre-professional programs in the health sciences and accelerated degree programs in engineering, law, accounting and business administration. Popular programs include nursing, engineering and biology. Classroom knowledge is put into practice at Mercer. More than 70% of students participate in at least one internship, over 30% of students engage in undergraduate research and thousands of students and faculty take part in Mercer on Mission international service-learning trips. Mercer pride is brought to life through the more than 140 student organizations and NCAA Division I athletics. In addition to the traditional undergraduate experience in Macon, students can get involved at the graduate and professional campus in Atlanta. About 96% of the class of 2020 are employed or in graduate school. The School of Music and the College of Nursing had 100% career outcomes for 2020 graduates.

name: University of Nevada, Las Vegas
description: What happens in Vegas doesn’t stay in Vegas—students of the University of Nevada, Las Vegas make an international impact. Students of the public research institution can choose from more than 300 majors, as well as online degree programs. Business, psychology and the health professions are among the most popular programs. In 2020, 7,000 undergraduates participated in research that received almost $300,000 in funding. UNLV has 50 research centers and institutes across a wide range of disciplines. The 350-plus acre campus is located minutes away from the Las Vegas strip and a few hours away from other Southwest destinations like Los Angeles and Phoenix. Campus life offers more than 350 student organizations and service opportunities. One-third of students are first-generation, and more than half are from underrepresented backgrounds. UNLV is designated as a Minority Serving Institution, an Asian-American and Native-American, Pacific Islander-Serving Institution and a Hispanic Serving Institution.
carnegieClassification: Doctoral Universities: Very High Research Activity

name: Whitman College
description: A small private liberal arts college in Walla Walla, Wash., Whitman provides students with a close-knit community, academic rigor, and a dynamic college experience. Whitman offers more than 60 academic majors, with popular areas in biology, psychology and political science. Each year presents a different academic theme to guide the Whitman community and integrate into the curriculum; the most recent theme was “Climate Justice, Climate Action.” The college offers over $42 million in financial aid & scholarships each year, and over 90% of Whitman students receive financial aid. Over half of Whitman students graduate debt free. Students are automatically considered for merit scholarships, including the prestigious Garrett-Sherwood Scholarships and the Eells Scholarship, which covers tuition and fees for four years plus a research grant. Students can remain active through campus organizations, including 12 club sports teams and a handful of intramural sports. Whitman fields 17 varsity athletics that compete in the Northwest Conference at the Division III level. Outside of athletics, students take advantage of the natural beauty of the nearby Blue Mountains. Whitman’s Outdoor Program runs weekend trips for kayaking, hiking, skiing and ice climbing. Perhaps the most notable of Whitmore alumni was Supreme Court Justice William O. Douglas—the longest-serving justice in U.S. Supreme Court history.

name: La Salle University
description: La Salle University is a Catholic liberal arts institution in Philadelphia that aims to provide a well-rounded education for a diverse campus: Students of color constitute some 50% of the student body and 45% receive Pell Grants. The university has 38 undergraduate fields of study and pre-professional programs. Nursing and marketing are among the most popular majors. La Salle offers full-tuition merit scholarships for some first-year students, as well as a $5,000 scholarship for students who have shown dedication to community service. There are about 175 clubs and organizations on campus, including 13 club sports, 17 honor societies and more than two dozen academic clubs. The La Salle Explorers compete in 17 NCAA Division I sports teams. Since 1948, 16 La Salle University student athletes have appeared in the Olympics, three of whom earned gold medals.

name: Yeshiva University
description: Yeshiva is a private Jewish university in New York City that offers students an education in secular knowledge and faith-based Jewish studies. The university operates four campuses throughout Manhattan and Bronx boroughs. Yeshiva students can choose from more than 65 majors and minors across three undergraduate schools and take advantage of specialized learning through its 8:1 student-to-faculty ratio. Yeshiva awards over $45 million in financial aid annually. Typically, more than 600 incoming students choose to begin their Yeshiva education with a year of Torah study in Israel. Students can combine the study of traditional Jewish theology with business, technology, and bioethics. All food served through the school’s dining services is certified kosher. The Yeshiva Maccabees compete in 15 NCAA teams. Within six months of graduating, about 96% of Yeshiva students pursue graduate school or are employed. The university has more than 70,000 alumni, which includes former governor of Vermont Howard Dean and author Chaim Potok.

name: Portland State University
description: Portland State University is a large public research university in the Oregon city’s downtown. Portland State encourages eco-friendly forms of transportation, and bikes can be rented for $45 per semester. Nearly 80% of students hail from Oregon, and in-state residents enjoy a $19,000 tuition discount compared to their out-of-state peers. Portland State offers a free food market with fresh produce and other healthy options to address food insecurity on campus. The market has served more than 350,000 pounds of food to 13,000 Portland State students. Notable Portland State alumni include D. Scott Davis, former UPS CEO, Carolyn Davidson, creator of the Nike swoosh logo, and Barbara Roberts, former Oregon governor.

name: Wentworth Institute of Technology
description: Wentworth Institute of Technology is a technical school with a 31-acre campus in Boston’s Fenway neighborhood. Construction management is Wentworth’s most popular major. The program’s curriculum includes elements of business administration, mathematics, chemistry and design to prepare students for the construction industry. Wentworth’s academic philosophy is centered on hands-on learning, and there are more than 60 laboratories, studios and maker spaces on campus. All undergraduates must complete two co-ops, and 57% of students were offered full-time jobs by their co-op employer. Wentworth graduates earn higher salaries than their counterparts at peer institutions, reporting an average early-career salary of $64,100.

name: Gettysburg College
description: Gettysburg College is a private liberal arts institution stationed near the historic Civil War battlefield in Gettysburg, Pa. Gettysburg offers 40 majors and 40 minors for its 2,400 students to choose from. The most popular majors are political science, organizational and management studies and economics. Students can apply their knowledge through other academic means, like studying abroad, where 60% of Gettysburg students spend a semester abroad, learning overseas in multiple countries like Egypt, Singapore and Germany. Student research is highly encouraged, with more than half of all students participating in student-faculty research. Gettysburg offers several academic merit scholarships; the largest award totals $44,000 annually. Just one year after graduation, 98% of alums are employed or attend graduate school. Gettysburg’s thriving location allows students to make the most of their time. The campus is only an hour from Baltimore, 90 minutes from Washington, D.C., and about two hours from Philadelphia. For those who elect to remain near campus, there are more than 120 clubs and organizations in student government, performing arts, campus media and various sports clubs. The Bullets sponsor 24 varsity sports that compete at the NCAA Division III level in Centennial Conference. As part of the first-year experience, Gettysburg students walk half a mile to the National Cemetery to recreate the historic tradition of hearing the Gettysburg Address delivered by President Abraham Lincoln. During the holidays, Thanksgiving Dinner allows Gettysburg students to fill up on plenty of food, served by professors.

name: Macalester College
description: Macalester College in Saint Paul, Minn. offers a strong liberal arts education grounded in internationalism, multiculturalism and service. The highly selective college admitted less than 30% of its applicant pool into the Fall 2023 entering class. Macalester students choose from over 60 majors, minors and concentrations. Mathematics, economics and computer science are all popular. Its location in the Minneapolis/St. Paul metro area allows more than 60 courses to partner with local businesses and organizations. Over 200 internship sites lie within eight miles of campus. Global learning opportunities abound, with more than half of students taking advantage of Macalester’s 95 study-away programs. All first-year applicants are automatically considered for merit scholarships; recipients are awarded for eight semesters with no minimum GPA for renewal. The Scots compete in the Minnesota Intercollegiate Athletic Conference at the Division III level. While there are no fraternities or sororities at Macalester, students can choose from more than 100 student organizations to build community. Popular Mac traditions include painting the rock on campus, and midnight breakfast at Cafe Mac, served by faculty.

name: College of Charleston
description: College of Charleston is a public institution in the heart of South Carolina’s oldest city. Deeply committed to the liberal arts and sciences, the atmosphere is civically and globally-minded. The college offers 64 majors, 82 minors and 25 interdisciplinary minors, such as data science and environmental and sustainability studies. Many students study business, political science or biology. The college’s career center is known for its partnerships with large companies. About 67% of the class of 2019 students completed at least one internship, and 81% were employed within one year by the time they graduated. There are more than 240 clubs on campus for students to join, as well as 28 Greek life chapters.  In the Honors College, students take interdisciplinary courses, engage in local community organizations, meet faculty in the college, and participate in research or internship opportunities.

name: California State University-Bakersfield
description: One of the younger members of the California State University system, CSU Bakersfield is a midsize public university in Bakersfield, CA, that offers a personalized 18:1 student to faculty ratio. CSU Bakersfield offers more than 55 undergraduate majors, including popular programs in business, psychology and law enforcement. There are more than 100 student organizations at CSU Bakersfield, including Greek life. The Bakersfield Roadrunners compete in 18 sports in the NCAA Division 1 Big West Conference. Notable alumni include House Minority Leader Kevin McCarthy and mixed martial artist Tito Ortiz.

name: University of the Pacific (CA)
description: Founded in 1851 as California’s oldest university, the University of the Pacific remains a pioneer in higher learning. The university prides itself on being California's first coeducational university and continues to be the only Methodist-affiliated university in the state. The university’s main campus is located in Stockton, Calif. and the school operates additional campuses in Sacramento and San Francisco. Pacific has a combined enrollment of nearly 6,300 students as of Fall 2022. The university offers around 80 undergraduate programs across nine schools and colleges. The majority of undergraduates take an experiential learning course, where they apply knowledge from the classroom to internships that count for academic credit. Pacific awards academic merit scholarships to both first-year undergraduate students and transfer students. The university is home to more than 150 clubs and student organizations. Pacific reported that 91% of students were working in their field or continuing their education within six months of graduating. The Pacific Tigers play at the Division I level and compete in the West Coast Conference. Students often participate in “Pacific Fridays,” a relatively new school tradition from 2021 where each week, the community wears orange, tiger stripes, and more to show school pride. Notable alumni include baseball agent Scott Boras, holder of the top spot on Forbes’ most powerful sports agent list, and astronaut Jose Hernandez.

name: Northern Arizona University
description: Northern Arizona University in Flagstaff, AZ is a public research university that utilizes its location to enhance its educational offerings. The university offers over 100 degrees, including fully online programs through seven undergraduate colleges and the only nationally accredited teacher education program in Arizona. Business, health and education are among the most popular areas of study. NAU is a hub for innovation, home to eight centers and institutes that focus on disciplines from Indigenous health to ecological restoration. Students also engage through other hands-on experiences, like the Grand Canyon Semester, an interdisciplinary experience that takes places in northern Arizona and the Colorado Plateau. Campus thrives with more than 400 organizations, Greek life, Division I athletics and outdoor adventures like rafting and hiking. Merit scholarships range up to $11,000 annually for out-of-state students and full tuition for Arizona residents.

name: Texas State University
description: Among the largest universities in the nation, Texas State University is located in San Marcos, Texas, less than an hour from Austin and San Antonio. About 40% of Texas State students identify as Hispanic. The university has received $48 million through Hispanic-Serving Institution funding from agencies such as the Department of Education, NASA and the USDA through since 2011. Texas State offers more than 180 majors and minors, ranging from agriculture business management to southwestern studies. President Lyndon B. Johnson was a Texas State alumnus, and he is commemorated on campus with a life-size statue and the LBJ Student Center.

name: Ramapo College of New Jersey
description: Located in Mahwah, NJ, Ramapo College of New Jersey is a public liberal arts college founded in 1969 that continues to add opportunities for students pursuing different fields. In fall 2020, the college introduced the first cohort of students studying data science. There are 67 majors at RCNJ, as well as 54 minors and 28 concentrations.  Students can join more than 100 clubs and organizations on campus, including many club sports and cultural organizations. About half of these clubs were inactive during the COVID-19 pandemic and plan to restart in fall 2021.  The college offers more than 500 study abroad programs in more than 60 countries. Some students complete an internship while attending an abroad program.  The college did not increase the cost of tuition and fees for the 2021-22 academic year. All applicants are automatically considered for merit scholarships. There are also scholarships for students who graduated from a New Jersey community college.

name: Xavier University
description: Xavier University is a Jesuit Catholic school in the heart of Cincinnati, OH, providing a core curriculum in a Catholic, liberal arts education. True to the school’s Jesuit tradition, Xavier students tally more than 80,000 hours of service annually. A member of the Division I Big East Conference, Xavier fields 18 varsity teams, known as the Musketeers. The men’s basketball team’s rivalry with the University of Cincinnati’s team, known as the Crosstown Shootout given the schools’ proximity, is one of the best in all of college basketball. About 20 percent of undergraduates major in the Williams College of Business. Other popular fields of study include nursing, liberal arts and biology. Nearly all undergraduates receive grant or scholarship aid, some through Xavier’s multicultural scholarships, such as the Weninger Scholarship named after the founder of the first Catholic Church in Cincinnati dedicated to serving the black community. Former Speaker of the House John Boehner, NBA All-Star David West and Pulitzer Prize-winning author Garry Wills all went to Xavier.

name: Rochester Institute of Technology
description: Rochester Institute of Technology is a private research university located in Henrietta, New York —part of the Rochester, New York, metropolitan area. The school is home to the National Technical Institute for the Deaf, which is the first and largest technological college for deaf and hard of hearing students. The school serves more than 1,100 deaf and hard of hearing students who live and study with hearing students. RIT prides itself on its collaborative, diverse community working at the intersection of art, design and technology. The institution offers a series of multidisciplinary, “future-proof,” academic programs called “New Economy Majors,” including Human-Centered Computing, Microelectronic Engineering, Motion Picture Science and Humanities, Computing, and Design. RIT alumni have won more than a dozen combined Pulitzer Prizes for work in visual journalism. Beyond its New York campus, RIT has campuses in China, Croatia, Dubai and Kosovo.

name: Hofstra University
description: Located 25 miles outside of New York City in Hempstead, NY, Hofstra University is a private school on Long Island that offers a broad range of academics from the humanities to engineering and pre-professional programs.Journalism is one of the most popular majors at Hofstra. Students can learn from faculty with extensive experience in the news industry, such as Emmy Award-winning professor Mario Gonzalez.Hofstra has more than 200 student organizations, with numerous professional interest groups, from accounting and fashion. There are 19 fraternities and sororities on campus.Campus is home to six theaters, 18 restaurants and a 24/7 convenience store.Hofstra has produced some of the biggest names in entertainment, including Academy Award-winning filmmaker Francis Ford Coppola and Marvel Studios founder Avi Arad.

name: Fashion Institute of Technology
description: The Fashion Institute of Technology is a public college with a nine-building campus in New York City that offers undergraduate degrees in fashion design, fine arts, illustration, interior design, and more. The institute is part of the State University of New York system—one of the largest collections of schools in the country. Serving over 10,000 students, FIT occupies an entire block within the city. The institute encourages students to participate in passion projects and research opportunities, even providing thousands of dollars in funding to support certain collaborative and sustainable initiatives. More than 2,000 students live on campus, and FIT is home to more than 60 student organizations. The Fashion Institute of Technology Tigers fields 10 NJCAA Division III teams. Students celebrate FIT school spirit through a number of beloved traditions, such as Legacy Week for homecoming, as well as Grad Week, with a series of events like an annual block party to honor graduating students. Notable alumni include fashion designers Norma Kamali and Calvin Klein, interior designer Scott Salvato, and film director Joel Schumacher.

name: University of Saint Thomas (MN)
description: The largest private university in Minnesota, the University of Saint Thomas in St. Paul is a Catholic institution that values academic excellence, faith, the common good and the pursuit of truth. The university enrolls more than 9,000 students and offers more than 100 undergraduate majors and minors. Majors include Classics, economics, digital media, civil engineering and Catholic studies. The university offers a minor in Peace Engineering, which is designed to combine engineering technical skills and justice and peace studies analysis. Outside of their coursework, students choose from more than 100 clubs. More than 40% of students study abroad.

name: University of Northern Iowa
description: Since its inception as a teachers college, the University of Northern Iowa in Cedar Falls, IA, has emphasized hands-on service learning. Undergraduates can choose from over 90 majors across four colleges. Popular programs include elementary education, psychology and business administration. UNI funds hundreds of hours of research conducted by undergraduates during the academic year and over the summer. As part of the National Student Exchange, students can take their talents to a partner university while paying UNI tuition. Top destinations include the University of South Carolina, New Mexico State University and the University of Montana. Scholarships with automatic consideration range up to $14,000 for in-state students and $20,000 for out-of-state students. The Bright Scholars of Iowa awards provides the cost of attendance to a Pell Grant-eligible Iowa student with high academic achievements. Six months following graduation, approximately 80% of the Class of 2020 was employed and 13% was continuing their education. Historically, the majority—about 75%—of students remain in Iowa post-graduation.

name: University at Albany, SUNY
description: The University at Albany is a public research university in the State University of New York system. It was founded in 1844 as the first public institution in the state. Students can choose from more than 50 majors, including reputable programs in homeland security and public policy. Economics, computer science and business are also popular majors. The university offers a variety of study abroad programs, some major-specific, including many at a center in Spain. Students may also pursue an internship, research or service opportunity while abroad. There are more than 300 student-led organizations on campus, including 37 recognized Greek life chapters. Undergraduates in any discipline can participate in research and present their findings at an annual conference. The university spent $94.7 million on research and training expenditures in the 2019-20 academic year.
carnegieClassification: Doctoral Universities: Very High Research Activity

name: University of Tulsa
description: The University of Tulsa is a private, STEM-focused research institution in Tulsa, Okla. Founded in 1894, the university supports a student body of nearly 4,000 members. TU offers more than 70 bachelor’s programs across five colleges. Many students study computer science, mechanical engineering and petroleum engineering. Academic perks include a full-scale drilling rig and a 2,000-foot well for research and a hands-on experience. While the estimated undergraduate cost of attendance is over $60,000 for the 2023-24 academic year, 100% of first-year students receive financial aid. Perhaps the most competitive scholarship at TU is the Presidential Scholarship, which covers the full cost of tuition. The Golden Hurricane has more than 15 Division I teams and competes in the American Athletic Conference. School spirit is often showcased through street painting along the university’s athletic complex, seniors ringing the cupola bell after their very last exam, and perhaps the most unique, the Toilet Bowl flag football game—a tradition held for over 50 years by students living in John Mabee Hall, commonly known as “The John.”

name: Susquehanna University
description: Susquehanna University in Selinsgrove, PA, is a private liberal arts school that encourages students to engage in experiential learning. SU offers more than 100 majors and minors across four schools. Popular programs include communication studies, marketing and psychology. The university emphasizes learning outside of the classroom. SU requires all students to study off campus, and 95% choose to do so abroad. The SU Service Leaders program is a four-year internship program in which students work with community partners who focus on youth development. There are more than 150 student organizations, including Greek life, to engage with. Off campus, students take advantage of the wealth of state parks within two hours of the university. Students can also rent a bike from Outdoor Recreation, which also sponsors outdoor adventure trips. Merit awards range up to $38,000 annually.

name: California State University-Monterey Bay
description: California State University, Monterey Bay, is a public university in Monterey County that emphasizes educating low income and underserved communities. The university enrolls more than 6,000 students, with more than 40% of students coming from Monterey, San Benito and Santa Cruz counties. Half of all undergraduate students are first generation college students. CSU Monterey Bay offers a variety of undergraduate majors, including programs in business, psychology and computer science. The college is located a mile from the beach, which is the closest of all California State University campuses. Scenic Big Sur is located about 30 miles south of campus. Notable CSU Monterey Bay alumni include Gonzaga Women’s Basketball coach Lisa Fortier.

name: Loyola University Maryland
description: Loyola University Maryland is a Jesuit liberal arts school in Baltimore that gives students a traditional Jesuit education while preparing them for a diverse and changing world. LUM has more than 30 undergraduate majors. A large number of students study business administration or speech communications and rhetoric.  The university stresses the importance of experiential learning. More than 80% of students participate in a practicum, internship or field experience by the time they graduate. Approximately 92% of undergraduate students receive some form of financial aid. LUM provides merit scholarships of up to $30,000 for incoming students. Students take part in more than 200 clubs and organizations on campus, including 17 geared toward service. The university also has partnerships with 18 community service programs and projects.

name: Missouri University of Science and Technology
description: Originally founded as a school for mining engineers and surveyors in 1870, the Missouri University of Science and Technology in Rolla is now a hub for STEM learning in Missouri’s public university system. Majors include architectural engineering, geology and geophysics, metallurgical engineering and nuclear engineering and radiation science. There are more than 7,000 students at the university. Every student must participate in experiential learning, such as research, an internship or study abroad. Upon admission, all students are automatically considered for merit scholarships. There are more than 200 student clubs at Missouri S&T. More than 20% of students participate in 24 Greek life chapters.

name: New School
description: The New School is a private college in New York City’s Greenwich Village that specializes in the arts, design and humanities. The New School consists of five main schools: the Parsons School of Design, the College of Performing Arts, the New School for Social Research, the Eugene Lang College of Liberal Arts and the Schools of Public Engagement. With world-renowned design programs, Parsons is the most well-known of the bunch, and about 60% of New School students major in the visual and performing arts. The New School’s campus extends from 11th to 16th Streets along Fifth and Sixth Avenues, just steps away from New York University. Designer Marc Jacobs and actor Bradley Cooper are two New School alumni that have thrived in the arts.

name: East Carolina University
description: East Carolina University, part of the University of North Carolina system, is a public university committed to service and research. ECU offers more than 80 undergraduate programs, as well as over 100 online degree and certificate programs. Upwards of 40% of undergraduates are enrolled in STEM or healthcare programs. ECU is the only public university in North Carolina with a medical school, dental school and college of engineering. The university is home to more than 10 research centers, institutes and field sites. Undergraduates can receive funding for mentored research, including the $1,000 UR Mini Awards. Students can take part in over 500 student organizations, including Greek life and Division I athletics. The majority of students hail from North Carolina. With about 35% of the freshman class identifying as first-generation college students, ECU was selected as a member of the 2021-22 First-gen Forward cohort by the Center for First-generation Student Success.

name: SUNY Maritime College
description: SUNY Maritime in Throggs Neck, New York, is part of the State University of New York system. The university enrolls more than 1,000 students and offers programs in engineering, science, as well as multiple U.S. Coast Guard license programs. SUNY Maritime offers two student pathways: the civilian program and the Regiment of Cadets. Civilian students follow a traditional degree program, while students in the Regiment of Cadets program embark on a “disciplined lifestyle program.” Cadets complete a Summer Sea Term, where cadets travel and gain experience operating and maintaining a ship. Civilian students, on the other hand, are required to complete a professional internship. SUNY Maritime alumni include astronaut Scott Kelly and U.S. Navy Cmdr. Kevin Mannix.

name: University of Rhode Island
description: Located in Kingston, Rhode Island, the University of Rhode Island is a public land-grant research university that provides students with a lively community. Undergraduates can choose from more than 90 majors. Popular fields include computer science, communications and criminology and criminal justice. The university is located minutes from the beach, 75 miles from Boston and 160 miles from New York City. URI provides grants of up to $1,000 to support individual undergraduate research projects. The university offers state-of-the-art research facilities, including a Digital Forensics and Cyber Security center and the Inner Space Center, a unique facility that allows for live ocean exploration. With more than 120 student organizations, Greek life, NCAA Division I sports and outdoor recreation at Rhode Island’s beaches, student life is abundant and varied.

name: Wheaton College (MA)
description: Wheaton College in Norton, MA, is a small liberal arts college that prides itself on a personalized education and co-curricular experiences. Students can choose from over 100 majors and minors. Popular programs include business, psychology and biology. Wheaton also offers dual degree programs in engineering and communications with nearby institutions. Wheaton stresses global education: About half of students study abroad, and Wheaton was the first college in the world to offer a study abroad program in Bhutan. There are over 100 student organizations on campus. Students can also engage with each other through theme houses, where residence is based around shared interests like the outdoors or politics. Six months after graduation, 97% of alumni in the five most recent classes were employed, pursuing further education or participating in internships, fellowships or service opportunities.

name: Art Center College of Design
description: The ArtCenter College of Design is a small, private art school in Pasadena, CA, that aims to combine key design principles with global thinking. ArtCenter offers just 11 majors, with programs in product design, fine art, advertising and automotive design. Students looking for a well-rounded education can minor in business, creative writing and social innovation. Scholarships are offered based on financial need and artistic and academic accomplishments. International students are considered for scholarships without recognition of financial need. There are no dorms at ArtCenter, but the college works with students to find housing in Los Angeles. Notable ArtCenter alumni include director Zack Snyder, Linkin Park musician Mike Shinoda and automobile designer Frank Stephenson.

name: Providence College
description: A private Catholic college in Rhode Island’s capital, Providence College is committed to the pursuit of truth and service of God. The university enrolls more than 4,000 students, with many hailing from New England. Finance, marketing, biology, management and psychology are among the most popular majors, according to data from Spring 2019. There are more than 300 study abroad programs and more than student organizations. Providence College is just five minutes from downtown Providence. The city offers shopping and an art scene, and is 50 miles from Boston and three hours from New York City. Providence is also home to a number of college campuses and thousands of college students.

name: Tennessee Technological University
description: Tennessee Tech is a midsize public research university in Cookeville, TN, that emphasizes hands-on education that leaves graduates career-ready. Students keep a large number of campus traditions alive, including the Kazoo Band at the annual homecoming parade and the “running of the freshman.” There are more than 200 student groups on campus, including Greek life. Tennessee Tech offers 41 majors, most with specialized concentrations. Its most popular programs are in mechanical engineering, computer science, exercise science and business. The school offers a number of merit-based scholarships, particularly for students from Tennessee. It also offers a special scholarship to the champion of Tennessee’s annual State Scholastic Chess Championship. Notable TTU alumni include astronaut Barry Wilmore and Boeing CEO Harry Stonecipher.

name: Michigan Technological University
description: Michigan Technological University in Houghton, Michigan, is a public research university that prides itself on its expansive hands-on experiences. Undergraduates can choose from over 60 majors, and the school assures students they can find a place where they can “geek out” with like minded classmates. Majors include audio production and technology, construction management, forestry and medical laboratory science. The university pays students for more than 100,000 hours of research annually. The Summer Undergraduate Research Fellowship provides awards of up to $4,000 for students who conduct research with a faculty mentor over the summer. There are over 200 student organizations.

name: University of West Florida
description: The University of West Florida in Pensacola, FL is a public university that has a large in-state student population and is a major driver of economic impact in Northwest Florida. UWF offers over 60 undergraduate majors across five colleges and online. Popular programs are in the health professions, business and computer and information sciences. The university’s other location, UWF Emerald Coast, offers curriculums for traditional and non-traditional students who have earned 60 or more semester hours. UWF grants more than 150 travel awards annually to present research at national conferences, and students are eligible to request up to $500 to assist with research materials. Minutes away from the beach, the 1,600-acre campus is home to twenty-five miles of hiking and biking nature trails, as well as 150 student organizations. Scholarships range up to full tuition, including the National Merit Finalist Scholarship and the Argo Spirit Scholarship for Pell Grant-eligible, first-time Florida residents.

name: Centre College
description: Centre College is a private liberal arts school in Danville, Kentucky. The university says it is committed to providing “an intensely personal education” filled with opportunities for hands-on, research and global experiences. The university offers majors in anthropology, chemical physics, German studies, religion and theater, among others. There are more than 1,000 students at the university. More than 80% of students study abroad – and one third of students study abroad multiple times. The university offers more than 80 clubs and fields NCAA Division III teams. Centre College says it is committed to making the private education affordable, adding that more than 90% of students don’t pay the sticker price. The campus is situated in the state’s Bluegrass region, offering breweries, theaters, parks, cafes and festivals. Centre College is also close to kayaking, hiking, horseback riding and biking opportunities.

name: California State University-San Marcos
description: California State University-San Marcos is a large public university in northern San Diego County that emphasizes professional readiness. The university offers more than 40 bachelor’s degrees. Business administration, psychology, criminology and biological sciences are among the most popular undergraduate majors. The school also offers a 14-week Community & Healthcare Interpreter Certificate to train participants who speak English and another language to become a community interpreter in various settings, including healthcare, business and education. The university is minutes to beaches and an hour to mountains and desert. The campus is home to more than 100 student organizations, including cultural, religious and sports clubs, among others. The school participates in the Middle Class Scholarship program for California families that earn up to $201,000.

name: University of California-Merced
description: Founded in 2005, the University of California, Merced, is the youngest of the 10 schools in the University of California system. It places an emphasis on interdisciplinary learning, diversity and sustainability. UC Merced offers 24 majors across three colleges. Its engineering programs are particularly notable, with strengths in bioengineering and environmental engineering. Fewer than 1% of UC Merced’s student body comes from outside of California. 50% of students identify as Hispanic, and 75% are first-generation college students. UC Merced has an impressive commitment to sustainability. It has built 17 buildings on campus that are LEED certified for new construction, set ambitious carbon neutrality goals and acquired 25,000 acres of grassland for conservation and research. The school has put over $200 million into research since 2006, and houses the Sierra Nevada Research Center.

name: University of Alabama in Huntsville
description: The University of Alabama in Huntsville is a public space-grant university in northern Alabama. NASA’s Marshall Space Flight Center is located in Huntsville, and much of UAH’s research is done in conjunction with the government agency. Fittingly, aerospace engineering is one of the most popular majors at UAH. More than a quarter of students major in engineering. Huntsville’s climate may be warm and humid, but that doesn’t stop the school from hitting the ice. The UAH Chargers are one of only two Division I hockey teams in the Sun Belt. Notable UAH alumni include NASA Outstanding Leadership Medal-winning astronaut Jan Davis and Discovery Communication founder John Hendricks.
carnegieClassification: Doctoral Universities: Very High Research Activity

name: University of North Florida
description: With a campus spanning more than 1,300 acres in urban Jacksonville, FL, the University of North Florida is a public university that is near a nature preserve, hiking trails and lakes. UNF offers 60 different bachelor’s programs for students to choose from. Psychology is the most popular area of study, closely followed by communications, business and nursing. There are more than 200 active student organizations on campus, including 32 Greek life organizations. There are numerous need-based and merit scholarships available at UNF, such as a scholarship for Pell grant recipients who graduated top ten from a Florida high school, as well as a state-funded grant for first-generation college students. Each college within the university also has their own department-based scholarships.

name: University of Mary Washington
description: The University of Mary Washington in Fredericksburg, VA, is a public university that provides intimate and interactive learning for undergraduates. Students choose from over 40 majors, as well as a five year masters program in education. Popular programs include business administration, psychology and biology. Located about an hour from Washington, D.C., students take advantage of experiential learning opportunities through internships, research and leisure activities. Over 100 undergraduates receive grants to participate in research.  The university offers full scholarships for Virginia residents through the “Washington Scholars” program and for out-of-state students through the “Alvey Scholars” program. Of the Class of 2020 respondents, approximately 89% were employed, attending graduate school, or otherwise pursuing careers. Of those in graduate school, over 80% stayed in Virginia.

name: Abilene Christian University
description: Abilene Christian University in Abilene, TX, is a private university that educates students for Christan service and leadership. Undergraduates can choose from over 70 majors in the arts and sciences, business, education, nursing and biblical studies. ACU has a satellite campus in Addison, TX, which serves as the hub to the university’s online programs. ACU offers study abroad opportunities with its faculty in Oxford, England; Montevideo, Uruguay; and Leipzig, Germany, and about 40% of students learn internationally. The university also provides faculty-guided funding to promote undergraduate research, up to $10,000. Spiritual formation is a cornerstone of the ACU experience, and students are required to attend daily chapel services and practice Christian values, like chastity outside of marriage. Students also get involved in more than 100 student organizations, including Greek life, and global and domestic missions. ACU has a block tuition system in which students can take up to 36 hours across the fall, spring and summer sessions for one price. Automatic merit awards range from $10,000 to $19,000 annually.

name: Bard College
description: Situated on 1,000 acres overlooking the Hudson River and the Catskill Mountains, Bard College in Annandale-on-Hudson, NY, stresses the importance of multidisciplinary studies and rigorous liberal arts education. The college has 35 standalone majors across four divisions, as well as the option for interdivisional programs and concentrations. Students who study fine arts or social sciences make up more than half of the student body. There are more than 150 student clubs on campus, including a variety of performing arts groups, political organizations and service opportunities. About 73% of undergraduate students receive financial aid from the college, covering on average 63% of the cost of attendance. The college offers many scholarships, such as the “New Generation” Scholarship for those whose parents were born outside of the U.S.

name: Colorado State University, Fort Collins
description: Colorado State University is a public research institution that values community, responsibility and inclusion to instill academic excellence in every student. Home to more than 33,000 students, the main campus sits in close proximity to downtown Fort Collins and the Rocky Mountains. CSU offers more than 100 majors and concentrations; the most popular in communications, family studies, business and psychology. Heavily grounded in research, CSU is recognized as an R1 research institution and spent $456 million in research funding in 2022. More than 5,000 undergraduates participate in research, which is showcased at events or published in CSU’s undergraduate research journal. About 60% of all CSU students receive grant and scholarship aid for both in-state and non-resident students. The university has merit scholarships of up to $10,000 and a Native American Legacy Award for students who are members of an Indigenous tribe. There are more than 500 student organizations, and all first-year students are required to stay on campus for the first two semesters. The CSU Rams compete in 16 NCAA Division I varsity teams in the Mountain West Conference. The Rams’ rivalry is particularly evident against CSU’s in-state rival, the University of Colorado Boulder Buffaloes. The highly anticipated faceoff is known as the “Rocky Mountain Showdown” and both teams agreed to continue the tradition through 2038. The team is cheered on by CSU’s live mascot CAM the Ram and looked after by student volunteers known as the Ram Handlers.
carnegieClassification: Doctoral Universities: Very High Research Activity

name: Butler University
description: Butler in is a private university in Indianapolis, IN, that emphasizes experiential and service learning. Undergraduates can choose from over 80 majors. Popular programs include marketing, finance, biology and health sciences. A Butler education is highlighted by the core curriculum, which involves community engagement, cultural and social justice requirements. Over 75% of students complete one or more internships and about 40% study abroad during their time at Butler. The “Butler Tuition Guarantee” is based on financial need and awards up to full tuition for high achieving students from Marion County in Indiana. Approximately 97% of Class of 2020 respondents were employed or in graduate school.

name: Sarah Lawrence College
description: Sarah Lawrence College emphasizes personal connection between faculty and students. The small private liberal arts college in Yonkers, NY, spans 44 acres and is a 30-minute train ride outside of Manhattan. Sarah Lawrence College became coeducational in 1968, but female students make up about 71% of the student body. Students do not have majors with course requirements, and instead work with faculty advisors to establish a course plan. Popular courses include creative writing and the performing arts.  More than 75% of students receive a grant or scholarship. Students are automatically considered for merit scholarships. Notable alumni include fashion designer Vera Wang, director J.J. Abrams, journalist Barbara Walters, and former Chicago mayor and member of Congress Rahm Emanuel.

name: Taylor University
description: Taylor is a non-denominational Christian liberal arts school in Upland, IN, that shapes its educational mission through building faith. Taylor’s liberal arts core curriculum emphasizes spiritual foundations, physical health, the fine arts, civic engagement, public speaking and math and sciences. Students sign the “Life Together Covenant,” which requires students to live by Biblical responsibilities and forbids homosexual behavior, premarital sex and drunkenness. Taylor doesn’t monitor chapel attendance, but students often attend services. Hundreds of students study abroad, and can earn credit as short-term missionaries to U.S. cities. Academic awards range up to $16,000, and other merit scholarships are awarded for arts, athletics and music. Indiana students are eligible for special scholarships. Approximately 98% of graduates were employed or in graduate school within six months of graduation.

name: Ithaca College
description: Perched on South Hill with a scenic view of Cayuga Lake, Ithaca College in the vibrant college town of Ithaca, NY, is known for its hands-on learning opportunities across a wide range of disciplines. Undergraduates can choose from nearly 100 majors across five schools, including the Roy H. Park School of Communications and School of Health Sciences and Human Performance, which offers a six-year Doctor of Physical Therapy program. The college is also known for its prestigious music and theater programs. There are more than 200 student organizations on campus, and no Greek life. IC is home to award-winning student-run media, including the ICTV television station, WICB and VIC radio stations and The Ithacan, the independent newspaper. IC offers numerous scholarships, including the prestigious merit-based Park Scholar Program award, which covers the cost of attendance, the Martin Luther King Scholar Program award for students of color and the S-STEM Scholar Program for students majoring in computer science, mathematics or physics. President Shirley M. Collado resigned from her position in July, and La Jerne Cornish is serving as the interim president.

name: Biola University
description: Located about 18 miles away from Los Angeles in La Mirada, CA, Biola University offers a Christian education focused on spiritual growth and professional development. There are 64 majors for students to choose from across Biola’s nine undergraduate schools and colleges. Every student is required to take foundational courses in theology and the Bible. The university has merit scholarships ranging up to $20,000 a year for freshmen and transfer students. About 90% of undergraduates receive financial aid, which covers 52% of demonstrated need on average. Biola is home to many student traditions, such as “Mock Rock,” where groups of students lip-sync songs in front of screaming fans, and floor events where roommates find each other a date. In 2017, 70% of students completed at least one internship before graduating, and 90% of students reported finding employment or enrolling in graduate school within six months after graduation.

name: SUNY, Farmingdale State College
description: Farmingdale State College is a mid-sized member of the State University of New York system on Long Island. The university offers 40 bachelor’s degree programs, ranging from Aeronautical Science to Sustainable Agriculture. In response to New York’s passage of the Marijuana Regulation and Taxation Act, Farmingdale State recently introduced a certificate program in Cannabis Production and Management for students. Farmingdale State’s student body is home-grown: about 90% of students hail from Long Island’s Nassau and Suffolk Counties. The Farmingdale State alumni network is more than 100,000 strong, including former NASA Astronaut Fernando Caldeiro.

name: California State University Maritime Academy
description: The smallest campus of the California State University system and the only maritime academy on the West coast, the California State University Maritime Academy in Vallejo, CA, provides immersive, hands-on experiences for students. Cal Maritime offers seven majors: business administration, global studies and maritime affairs, marine transportation, mechanical engineering, facilities engineering technology, marine engineering technology and oceanography—the newest major. Over the summer, the Training Ship Golden Bear exposes students to the responsibility of running a vessel and international ports of call. Students are required to complete internships in shore-side companies, with government agencies or aboard commercial ships. A staple to the academy experience is the being part of the Corps of Cadets, which includes adhering to shared uniform and grooming standards, living by core values, punctuality and supporting shipmates. There is no armed service obligation attached to graduation from Cal Maritime. The university offers the Presidential Scholarship for California residents valued at $6,000 annually, and is a member of the Western Undergraduate Exchange, which allows students from select states to attend at a reduced out-of-state tuition rate.

name: Northern Illinois University
description: Northern Illinois University is a large public university in DeKalb, IL, that offers a wide range of liberal arts and professional courses. Students at NIU can choose from over 100 majors, as well as a large number of accelerated programs that deliver a bachelor’s degree along with a master’s or law degree. NIU has a lively campus: Students can live in one of 5 large dormitories and participate in over 300 clubs and organizations. The NIU Huskies participate in the NCAA D1 Mid-American conference. All NIU students are automatically considered for merit scholarships, which are awarded to students with high GPAs. Students are also considered for the prestigious Presidential Scholars award, which covers full tuition. Notable NIU alumni include “Simpsons” voice actor Dan Castellaneta, “The Wire” actor Wood Harris and U.S. Senator Tammy Duckworth.

name: Soka University of America
description: Soka University of America is a private liberal arts college in Orange County, CA, founded on the Buddhist principles of peace, human rights and the sanctity of life. Students earn a BA in the liberal arts, with concentrations including environmental studies, humanities, international studies, life sciences, and social and behavioral sciences. Soka boasts intimate class sizes and a low student-to-faculty ratio of 8-to-1. International students make up over half of the student body. Undergraduates are required to study abroad in their language of study for a semester during their third year at no extra cost. Students whose family’s annual income is less than $60,000 will receive the Soka Opportunity Grant, which covers up to full tuition. Soka also offers a number of merit scholarships providing up to the cost of attendance.

name: California State University, Sacramento
description: California State University, Sacramento uses its robust location in the state’s capital city to educate a diverse student body. Boasting more than 30,000 students, Sacramento State is one of the largest schools in the California State University system. The university offers more than 30 academic majors from eight colleges, and popular areas of study include business, criminal justice, and communications. Rich in diversity, Sac State is designated as both an Asian American & Native American Pacific Islander Serving Institution and a Hispanic-Serving Institution, as a third of its student body identifies as Hispanic. In 2023, the university welcomed its ninth president, officially assuming the position in July. Sac State awards $4 million in scholarships every year to offset the cost of attendance. The university supports around 250 student organizations, which include many Greek Life chapters. The Sacramento State Hornets compete at the Division I level and are members of the Big Sky Conference. Surrounded by nature, Sac State’s campus is designated as a Tree Campus USA by the Arbor Day Foundation and is six miles from the State Capitol. Students look forward to annual events like “Phlagleblast,” which introduces them to campus vendors and resources decorated with fun themes like “Under the Sea” or a circus theme. Students often end each week by wearing Sac State gear on Fridays as a fun way of showing school spirit. Black Panther director Ryan Coogler, Academy Award-winning actor Tom Hanks and journalist Lester Holt all attended Sacramento State.

name: The Juilliard School
description: Located at Lincoln Center in Manhattan, the Juilliard School is a prestigious performing arts institution that prepares emerging musicians, dancers and actors to take center stage. Juilliard offers Bachelor of Fine Arts degrees in dance and drama, as well as 21 Bachelor of Music degrees. Although the school’s main purpose is to train artists, all undergraduate students take liberal arts classes in literature, philosophy, history, social sciences, arts, and languages. Students and faculty members put on more than 700 performances annually across 10 performance venues. The Kovner Fellowship covers tuition, room and board for classical musicians at the school. Juilliard also awards scholarships based on a combination of financial need and artistic merit. Notable alumni include Robin Williams, Yo-Yo Ma and Viola Davis.
carnegieClassification: Special Focus Four-Year: Arts, Music & Design Schools

name: New College of Florida
description: A small public liberal arts college in Sarasota, FL, the New College of Florida is the Florida state university system’s designated honors college. New College’s 110-acre campus is located directly overlooking the Sarasota Bay, an hour south of Tampa. The school’s freshman dormitories were designed by famous modernist architect I.M. Pei. The campus makes the most of its proximity to aquatis: The school hosts a marine biology research center, and for adventurous students, the “Bull Sharks Dive Club” is a student-run scuba diving group.  The Pritzker Marine Biology Research Center houses 100 aquaria of many different marine ecosystems, including a 15,000-gallon research and display tank. New College boasts one of the highest graduation rates in the country, and alumni gather annually for an on-campus clambake fundraiser.

name: Pace University
description: With campuses in downtown Manhattan and Westchester County, Pace University embodies the New York state of mind. Accounting is one of the most popular majors at Pace, and the school offers numerous dual-degree programs that include preparation for the Certified Public Accountant (CPA) exam. True to the character of Manhattan, Pace has strong arts programs in addition to its business pedigree. The BFA in Acting degree includes a trip to Los Angeles for students to experience the other American theater hub. It’s a family affair at Pace—parents of full-time undergraduates can take one Pace class for free each semester. Of Pace’s Class of 2020, 84% of students reported being employed, in graduate school or entering the military, with an average starting salary of $58,912.

name: University of Alaska, Fairbanks
description: Situated in Alaska’s interior region, the University of Alaska, Fairbanks is a public institution with a dedication to research and polar bears. UAF’s campus is just 120 miles south of the Arctic Circle. Much of the school’s research is arctic, such as a recent analysis of a 17,000-year-old wooly mammoth fossil housed on campus. The College of Fisheries and Ocean Sciences is one of UAF’s nine schools, educating future leaders in Alaska’s many rich fisheries. Named after the local Native Alaskan word for polar bear, the UAF athletic teams compete as the Nanooks. Fitting for its Alaska location, ice hockey, rifle and skiing are among the Nanooks’ 10 sports.

name: Denison University
description: Situated within the New England-style village of Granville, Ohio is Denison University, a private liberal arts school that emphasizes learning outside of the classroom. Founded in 1831, Denison is one of the earliest colleges established in the old “Northwest Territory,” during Andrew Jackson’s presidency. Denison’s admission rate sits at less than 30%; a testament to its competitive selection process. The university offers more than 40 majors to 2,300 undergraduates, including popular areas of study like economics, communications, and psychology. In 2022, Denison reported an endowment size that surpassed $1.1 billion. Denison boasts a thriving campus culture with more than 160 student organizations that include Greek life. 99% of all students live on campus. Denison Big Red athletics sponsors more than 20 NCAA D-III varsity teams, playing in the North Coast Athletic Conference. Campus quirks and traditions include climbing mountains, celebrating “D-Day,” an annual festival to honor the university, and grabbing a “Snagel,” or a toasted bagel with cream cheese and brown sugar—a fan favorite among students. Actor Steve Carell and actress Jennifer Garner are notable alums of the university.

name: University of Washington, Tacoma Campus
description: The University of Washington’s Tacoma Campus is one of the three campuses within the University of Washington system. The 46-acre campus is situated in downtown Tacoma, Wash., where nearly 5,000 students call UW Tacoma home. The university offers more than 50 undergraduate majors, of which, computer science, biomedical sciences and information technology are the most popular. UW Tacoma doesn't have to look far for talented students; more than 90% of students hail from Washington. More than half of enrollees identify as students of color. UW Tacoma’s endowment totaled nearly $60 million in 2022. Financial aid types range from scholarships and grants to child care assistance, which helps reduce the cost of attendance for students with kids under 13. Study abroad scholarships and student fellowships are also available to students looking to learn while traveling. Outside of the classroom, students can stay involved through student organizations, events, and recreation to stay active. To prioritize student health and wellness, UW Tacoma students automatically receive a membership to all YMCA locations around the country. Students are also encouraged to explore downtown Tacoma, a lively area with entertainment hubs like the Theater District as well as the Tacoma Dome for events, which seats more than 20,000 people.

name: The Catholic University of America
description: The Catholic University of America is a private research university in Washington, D.C. that serves as the national university of the Catholic faith in the U.S. Catholic’s 176-acre campus is the largest college campus in the nation’s capital. Political Science is the most popular major at Catholic. Majors can opt for a concentration in American government, political theory or world politics. New students at Catholic participate in the “First Year Experience,” a core curriculum that grounds students in the liberal arts. Catholic is the only American university to have the Pope visit campus three times, most recently, Pope Francis visited in 2015. Notable alumni include New York Yankees general manager Brian Cashman and actors Jon Voight and Susan Sarandon.

name: CUNY, Lehman College
description: Lehman College, an institution part of the City University of New York system located in the Bronx, is a liberal arts college with ample research opportunities. Undergraduates can choose from 80 majors and programs. Popular programs include nursing, business administration and psychology. Lehman boasts research strengths in a range of areas, including anthropology, biological sciences, chemistry, mathematics, computer science, psychology and physics and astronomy. The Science Hall was the first CUNY building to be awarded LEED Platinum certification, the highest sustainability ranking. The student body’s diversity is reflective of the city it is located in. Over 50% of students are first-generation, and more than half of the student body identifies as Hispanic/Latino. The majority of students hail from the Bronx and other New York City boroughs. Notable alumni include New York State Attorney General Letitia James and Bronx Borough President Rubén Díaz, Jr.

name: Rockhurst University
description: A small, Catholic school in Kansas City, MO, Rockhurst University offers students an intimate liberal arts education guided by Jesuit values. Rockhurst’s 55-acre campus is a mile from the upscale Country Club Plaza and four miles south of downtown Kansas City. vAbout half of Rockhurst students are Catholic. Regardless of major, all undergraduates completed a core curriculum centered on the Jesuit ideal of a well-rounded education with requirements in the arts, scientific inquiry and global perspectives. Roughly 40% of Rockhurst students are in the Bachelor of Science in Nursing degree program. Rockhurst nursing graduates report a $70,000 median salary and a 100% job placement rate. More than half of Rockhurst alumni remain in the Kansas City metropolitan area.

name: Boise State University
description: Boise State University is a public research institution located in the center of Idaho’s largest city. BSU offers more than 90 bachelor’s degrees, with the majority of students being enrolled in the College of Arts and Sciences, and the College of Health and Science has the largest nursing program in Idaho.Students can make the most of multiple options to be involved on campus, including starting their own organization that supports their interests or joining one of the 22 different Greek life organizations. BSU was one of five universities in the U.S. recognized by the Association of Public and Land-Grant Universities for innovative efforts to help students stay in college and complete their degree on time.

name: Rutgers University, Camden
description: Rutgers University-Camden is part of the four-campus Rutgers University system in New Jersey. The enrolls more than 6,000 students, with more than 90% of undergraduates residing in New Jersey. Classes consist of about 24 students, on average. The Camden campus was founded in 1926 as the South Jersey Law School and the College of South Jersey before it merged with Rutgers in 1950. The public university offers undergraduate degrees in accounting, biology, computer science, marketing and psychology, among others. Rutgers-Camden, home of the Scarlet Raptors, houses a NCAA Division III athletics program. The university is situated in a metropolitan area, with Philadelphia located just across the river. The Camden Waterfront, which offers a sports and entertainment scene, is just a short walk from campus.

name: Westmont College
description: Westmont College is a Christian liberal arts school that emphasizes leadership in academia, faith and global affairs. The school’s 111-acre campus is a shuttle ride away from downtown Santa Barbara, CA, as well as Butterfly Beach and East Beach. Westmont holds Chapel three times a week. There are more than 30 student-led ministries for students to participate in community service. Westmont offers about 30 undergraduate and 11 pre-professional programs for students to choose from. The most popular majors are kinesiology and business. Students are encouraged to study abroad. The college offers ten semester-long programs, many of which complement certain majors. Students may also spend a semester at one of 12 other colleges in the Christian College Consortium. About 95% of students receive scholarships or grants from Westmont. There are numerous merit scholarships, including one that covers 85% of tuition.

name: Saint John's University
description: The all-men Saint John’s University is one half of a pair of liberal arts institutions located in central Minnesota. The partnership between Saint John's and the College of Saint Benedict, its sister school with a campus six miles away, offers a combination of the benefits of a large school and that of a small school, the schools say. The colleges are minutes from the St. Cloud metropolitan area. Students can choose from more than 30 majors and 40 minors. The college experience is grounded in Catholic and Benedictine tradition. More than 40% of students are Catholic, and students of all faiths can apply. Students hail from more than 40 states and more than a dozen countries.

name: Embry-Riddle Aeronautical University, Prescott
description: Founded in 1978, Embry-Riddle Aeronautical University, Prescott is a residential university in Prescott, AZ. This university specializes in aviation, aerospace, security and intelligence. The second campus of Embry-Riddle Aeronautical University is home to the country's only College of Security and Intelligence, which focuses on programs including terrorism, information warfare, transportation security, illicit trafficking network, international crime and homeland security. The 539-acre campus features four academic colleges and offers 24 bachelor's degrees and two master's degrees. The school is home to nearly 35 labs, including the NASA Space Grant lab. Outside of class, ERAU Prescott offers over 120 diverse organizations, including Greek societies, academic clubs, intramural and sports clubs. The school offers scholarships for students to study in one of the nine study abroad programs across hundreds of locations. ERAU Prescott's Golden Eagles Flight team competes at both the regional and national level SAFECON competitions hosted by the National Intercollegiate Flying Association (NIFA) each year. The ramp at the Prescott Flight Line provides parking for more than 30 airplanes and 10 helicopters.

name: Spelman College
description: One of the oldest and most prestigious historically Black colleges and universities, Spelman is a private, women’s liberal arts college in Atlanta, GA, that is dedicated to fostering leadership and intellectual creativity in its students. Spelman offers 33 majors, as well as the opportunity for an Independent Study major and a dual degree program in engineering. It also offers special academic programs focused on the African diaspora, art and curatorial studies, Asian studies, and food studies. Campus life at Spelman is vibrant. 1,200 students live on campus in 11 distinct residence halls, where they participate in over 85 student groups, including Greek life. Students can opt to live in Living & Learning Communities dedicated to social justice, scholarship, public service and leadership. Graduates of Spelman are passionate about furthering their education: One third of alumni go on to graduate or professional school in their first year after graduating. Notable Spelman alumni include Pulitzer Prize winner Alice Walker, politician Stacey Abrams and Walgreens Boots Alliance CEO Rosalind Brewer.

name: University of Puget Sound
description: Located in Tacoma, WA, the University of Puget Sound is a private liberal arts school with ties to the United Methodist Church. A Puget Sound education emphasizes critical thinking and experiential learning. Puget Sound has an eight-course core curriculum, consisting of two freshman seminars and additional courses in art, math, humanist, natural science and social sciences. The school is partnered with 250 local groups in Tacoma for community-based learning programs. Business, Political Science and Psychology are amongst the school’s most popular majors. The school’s Slater Museum of Natural History holds various species of birds, mammals, reptiles, amphibians and plant specimens from the Pacific Northwest. Puget Sound is one of the top producers of Peace Corps volunteers, and the school offers a Peace Corps Prep certificate to prepare students for the program.

name: California State University, Stanislaus
description: California State University-Stanislaus is a public university with a main campus in Turlock, CA, in the golden state’s Central Valley. Stan State, which had more than 10,000 students in Fall 2022,  prides itself on preparing students for the future and its commitment to access and inclusion. More than 70% of students were first generation in Fall 2022. The school is home to a basic needs committee, undocumented student services program and a cross cultural center. Stan State offers more than 40 undergraduate programs and more than 80 student organizations and clubs. The Stanislaus State Warriors compete on 14 NCAA Division II teams.

name: Muhlenberg College
description: Muhlenberg College is a private liberal arts school affiliated with the Evangelical Lutheran Church in Allentown, PA. It’s particularly known for the strength of its teaching program. The college offers 38 majors, spanning from American Studies to Sustainability Studies—an examination of how to bring justice to ecological and environmental health. Muhlenberg’s School of Continuing Studies offers teaching certificates for nontraditional students. Muhlenberg participates in various academic partnership programs at other institutions. Dental students can take part in a program with the University of Pennsylvania School of Dental Medicine for a B.S. and a D.D.S. degree in 7 years. More than 96% of freshmen receive some form of financial aid. Before the pandemic, 56 percent of Muhlenberg students studied abroad.

name: St. Mary's College of Maryland
description: One of two public honors colleges in the country, St. Mary's College of Maryland is a small school 75 miles southeast of Washington, D.C.
