St. Mary’s academics are guided by the “Learning Through Experiential and Applied Discovery” (LEAD) principle. LEAD entails a core curriculum, study of a foreign language and a capstone project. Campus is home to a 100-seat movie theater, fire pits, a climbing wall and a 50-meter swimming pool. The St Mary’s River is immediately to the west of campus, and students can enjoy waterfront views from their dorm rooms and free access to kayaks, paddleboards and windsurfing equipment. Nearly 40% of the Class of 2020 studied abroad.

name: Iona University
description: Iona University is a tight-knit Catholic institution in New Rochelle, NY, with additional campuses in Bronxville and Westport, Ireland.Undergraduates can choose from almost 40 majors, and popular programs include finance, marketing and criminal justice, and graduate students have 25-degree programs to choose from. Approximately one-quarter of the incoming freshman class is pursuing health sciences. With more than 80 student organizations, including Greek life, and a location just an hour away from Manhattan, there is a wealth of opportunities for students. The college emphasizes community service and offers international mission trips. Approximately 94% of respondents in the Class of 2020 are employed or in graduate school six months following graduation.

name: Georgia State University
description: A large, public research university in the heart of Atlanta, Georgia State aims to ready students for professional work and establish a new generation of student leaders. Students at GSU can choose from 250 majors and minors, with popular programs in business, the social sciences and psychology. Georgia State has a very diverse student body, and is officially classified as a minority-serving institution: 41% of the student body is Black, 15% is Asian and 12% is Hispanic. The school’s “Baldwin Book Club” gives students a venue for discussing racial justice literature. GSU offers several merit-based scholarships, including the highly competitive Presidential Scholarship, which covers tuition and all fees, and the Achieve Atlanta scholarship for graduates of Atlanta’s public school system. Notable GSU alumni include rapper and actor Ludacris and former Bank of America CEO Ken Lewis.
carnegieClassification: Doctoral Universities: Very High Research Activity

name: Christopher Newport University
description: Christopher Newport University in Newport News, VA, is a public university that encourages hands-on experiences and a comprehensive liberal arts education. Students can choose from over 40 undergraduate majors, with popular programs in business, biology and psychology. CNU prides itself on its robust core curriculum, which requires the study of literature, composition, economics, mathematics, a foreign language, science and American history. Undergraduate research is a cornerstone of the CNU experience. The university provides funding for the mentored learning projects and summer research programs. There are more than 200 student organizations on campus, including Greek life. The community is tight-knit, as students are required to live on campus for their first three years. The President’s Leadership Program enrolls approximately 400 freshmen annually and integrates academic study, experiential learning and personal development. Students in the program receive a minimum $500 scholarship and funding for study abroad.

name: Morehouse College
description: Morehouse College is a private historically black men’s liberal arts college in Atlanta Georgia founded in 1867, two years after the end of the Civil War. The college offers 33 majors, with the most popular areas of study being business, biology and pre-engineering. Most Morehouse institutional scholarships are need-based. Recently, Morehouse made headlines when commencement speaker, billionaire Robert F. Smith, announced he would pay off every 2019 graduate’s student debt. Students can participate in 60 clubs and organizations, including the Morehouse College Glee Club, which performs across the world. The campus is home to more than 13,000 items produced by alum Martin Luther King Jr., including handwritten notes, speeches, manuscripts, and sermons. Morehouse alumni who join the ranks of Martin Luther King Jr. are director Spike Lee and Maynard Jackson, the first African American mayor of Atlanta. The school is also one of the top producers of Rhodes Scholars among historically black colleges.

name: University of Michigan-Dearborn
description: Founded in 1959 in part thanks to a $6.5 million gift from Ford Motor Company, the University of Michigan-Dearborn is located in the automotive company’s home city of Dearborn, MI.UM-Dearborn’s 17 research centers and institute span from the Dearborn Artificial Intelligence Research (DAIR) Center to an oral history archive of Holocaust survivors.Fitting given its Ford ties, Mechanical Engineering is the most popular major. Other popular fields include business and biological and biomedical sciences.92% of incoming undergraduates receive financial assistance and more than a third of students receive Pell grants.Of students that entered the workforce immediately after graduation, 90% remained in Michigan, while 8% of graduates chose to pursue graduate school.

name: California State University, East Bay
description: California State East Bay is a public university in Hayward, California in the San Francisco Bay Area. More than 14,000 students were enrolled Fall 2020 and more than 60% of undergraduates were first generation college students. Business Administration, Psychology, Health Science and Kinesiology are among the most popular undergraduate majors. The university offers a number of programs designed to serve low-income, underrepresented and underserved students. The Educational Opportunity Program, which supports access and retention for low-income and first generation students, is one such program. The university also offers a program to support students transitioning from community college. Notable CSUEB alumni include cartoonist Gene Luen Yang, Juniper Networks Chairman Scott Kriens and Tony Award winner James Monroe Iglehart.

name: Drew University
description: Known as The Forest for its tall trees, Drew University’s campus is a 50-minute train ride from New York City in Madison, NJ. The university guarantees housing for all four years, and about 90% of students live on campus. The university guarantees that students will have two résumé-ready experiences by the time they graduate. About 94% of students of new graduates find employment or enroll in graduate school within six months of graduating.  Drew offers 52 undergraduate majors for students to choose from. Business, economics and biology are the most popular areas of study among undergraduate students, but the university also has reputable graduate programs in the theology school.  Students take part in several annual traditions on campus, including festivities surrounding Halloween and Fernfest, when students work to protect and replenish the local environment. All first-year applicants are automatically considered for merit scholarships ranging from $10,000 to $25,000. The average financial aid package was around $32,000 in the 2020-21 academic year.

name: University of New Hampshire
description: The University of New Hampshire in Durham, NH is the state’s flagship research university and provides students with robust academics and extracurricular experiences.  Students choose from over 170 bachelor’s programs, with popular majors including business, engineering and biological and biomedical sciences. UNH has more than 50 research centers and institutes, and is known for its research in space plasma physics, ecology and technologies in partnership with NASA. The school is home to one of the largest undergraduate research conferences, with more than 1,800 students taking part annually. The university has more than 200 student organizations, including Greek life, which approximately 15% of students take part in. The Wildcats compete at the NCAA Division I level. Merit scholarships range up to $9,000 for New Hampshire residents (about half of the student body) and $12,000 for non-residents. Alumni include writer John Irving, “Frozen” director Jennifer Lee, astronaut Richard Linnehan and Baseball Hall of Fame inductee Carlton Fisk.
carnegieClassification: Doctoral Universities: Very High Research Activity

name: Siena College
description: Siena is a private college in Loudonville, NY, whose teachings are rooted in a Franciscan, liberal arts tradition. Siena offers almost 40 majors. Popular programs include marketing, psychology and accounting. As part of its core curriculum, students take courses in Franciscan heritage, diversity, social justice and nature. About 70% of students take part in hands-on experiences, like research and internships. The Stewarts Advanced Instrumentation and Technology Center, or SAInT Center, partners students with leaders in scientific instrumentation to provide training, research and educational opportunities. There are more than 100 student organizations at Siena, including Division I sports, but no Greek life. On average, “Saints” receive $23,000 from Siena. Students are automatically considered for academic scholarships. The Saint Francis Scholarship awards up to $12,000 over four years and is for residents from New York and border states. About 90% of recent graduates are employed or continuing their education.

name: Concordia College—Moorhead
description: Concordia College in Moorhead, MN, is a private Christian college founded by a group of Norwegian-American Lutherans in 1891. Business, education, and biology top the list of the school’s most popular majors. Through the college’s Postsecondary Enrollment Options (PSEO), students at selected Minnesota public schools can enroll in university courses at no cost. All students who have a 4.0 GPA are guaranteed to be awarded with the Excellence Scholarship, receiving $26,000 a year. There are more than 100 student organizations and over 19 music ensembles, including the Concordia Choir and the Percussion Ensemble.With a network of 32,000 alumni around the world, students have access to multiple connections throughout a variety of industries and professions.

name: Central Connecticut State University
description: Central Connecticut State University is the state’s oldest publicly funded university, serving the community for over 170 years. Undergraduates can choose from over 80 degree programs across four colleges and schools: Arts and Sciences, Business, Education and Professional Studies, and Engineering, Science and Technology. Computer science, business/marketing and education are the top majors. CCSU has over 20 partnerships and exchanges in 17 countries and offers courses abroad in the winter, spring and summer sessions. CCSU also offers a six-month co-op employment program for students. There are over 100 student organizations and NCAA Division I sports at the university. The majority of students hail from Connecticut, and less than a quarter live on campus. Campus is located about 15 minutes from Hartford, the state capital, and two hours from New York City and Boston. More than 85% of CCSU graduates remain in Connecticut.

name: Milwaukee School of Engineering
description: At the Milwaukee School of Engineering, students gain a tight-knit education and learn the values of work ethic and industry knowledge. The school, in downtown Milwaukee, WI, guarantees that students will graduate in four years and take courses for their major starting on day one. The college offers undergraduate degrees in 24 disciplines in engineering, nursing and other STEM fields. Mechanical and electrical engineering are the most popular programs.  MSOE has many scholarships, including some that fall under certain academic achievements, a full-tuition diversity merit scholarship, and a $1,000 per year scholarship for legacy students.  Students follow many traditions at the school, including Crocktoberfest, when students taste crockpot meals made by faculty and staff, and an annual ski and snowboard backpacking trip to northern Michigan. About 95% of students found employment or enrolled in graduate school shortly after graduating. The average starting salary of a graduate was around $65,000.

name: Missouri State University
description: Founded in 1905 in Springfield, Missouri State University is the second largest university in Missouri. MSU offers 102 undergraduate and 61 postgraduate programs, with business, health and human services and arts and letters as the most popular areas of study. In addition to its Springfield location, the school has two other campuses in Missouri, as well as one in Dalian, China. Freshmen and currently enrolled MSU students may apply for a variety of merit-based scholarships, including automatic scholarships given to those with high standardized test scores. MSU’s Bears compete in the NCAA’s Division I, and most teams belong to the Missouri Valley Conference, though the football team is a member of the Missouri Valley Football Conference and men’s swimming competes in the Mid-American Conference. MSU has 34 fraternities and sororities and over 200 clubs and organizations. Since 1963, MSU students have put on productions in the outdoor Tent Theatre, which now operates as a professional company where students work alongside experienced actors from around the country. Alumni include actors John Goodman and Kathleen Turner, former Walmart CEO David Glass, as well as former MLB first baseman Ryan Howard.

name: University of Minnesota, Duluth
description: A mid-sized public university on scenic Lake Superior, the University of Minnesota Duluth is best known for its dominance on the ice. Hockey is king at UMD. The Minnesota Duluth Bulldogs’ women’s hockey team has captured five NCAA Division I national championships, while the men’s squad has won three national titles. The university offers 15 undergraduate degrees in 84 majors. Psychology, marketing and mechanical engineering are the most popular fields of study. UMD’s Natural Resources Research Institute is a leader in applied science and engineering research in Minnesota, with two industrial research facilities dedicated to finding solutions in bioenergy, manufacturing and other fields. The 244-acre lakeside campus includes 60 acres of forested trails.

name: California State University, Channel Islands
description: California State University, Channel Islands, is a midsize public university in Camarillo, CA, that is the youngest member of the California State University system. Students at CSUCI can choose from majors in 27 fields of study, with popular programs in business, psychology and healthcare professional services. Half of CSUCI’s student body is Hispanic, and the school was designated a Hispanic Serving Institution in 2010. Students at CSUCI can make the most of its coastal surroundings with free recreational opportunities at the Channel Islands Boating Center. The university also maintains a research station on the Channel Islands that monitors seacliff erosion, wetland water quality and stream restoration. 83% of students at CSUCI receive financial aid.

name: Saint Joseph's University (PA)
description: Founded in 1851 a block from Independence Hall in Philadelphia, Saint Joseph’s University is a sprawling private Jesuit school known for its demanding academics and small student to faculty ratio. More than half of students at Saint Joseph’s major in the Haub School of Business. Haub offers 15 majors, including unique options like Family Business and Entrepreneurship, Food Marketing and Machine Learning for Business Applications. Students that participate in SJU’s Cooperative Education Program (co-op) can graduate in four years with one full year of work experience. All students at Saint John’s are automatically considered for merit scholarships. The Class of 2020’s most common employers include the Children's Hospital of Philadelphia, Teach for America and the U.S. Department of State.

name: LIU Post
description: Long Island University is a large private university in Brookville, NY, that offers a wide variety of in-person, online and nonresidential courses. It has a second main campus in Brooklyn. Students at LIU can pursue 49 majors, ranging from professional programs in veterinary technology and pharmacy to liberal arts degrees in film and English. Its nursing and healthcare programs are particularly popular. Greek life is central to the residential experience at LIU’s Brookville campus, though the school has removed 17 chapters since 2010. National Merit Scholars are considered for the full tuition Provost’s Award for Scholastic Excellence. There are also a number of scholarships for students transferring from Long Island community colleges. Notable LIU alumni include Fox News anchor Brian Kilmeade, former Yahoo CEO Terry Semel and billionaire hedge fund manager Ray Dalio.

name: South Dakota State University
description: A midsize public land grant university in Brookings, SD, South Dakota State University aims to encourage students’ creativity, innovation and public citizenship. The largest university in South Dakota, SDSU offers 80 majors and 97 minors, ranging from aerospace engineering to wildlife and fisheries science. SDSU is a leader in agriculture, remote sensing and resource management. In 2019 the school spent $67.6 million on research. Students can apply for summer research funding to get hands-on experience. There’s plenty to do in the college town of Brookings. The school supports over 240 student organizations, and the NCAA D1 Jackrabbits play in 17 sports. Notable SDSU alumni include former US Senator Tom Daschle and IBM computer architect Gene Amdahl.

name: SUNY, College at New Paltz
description: The only residential public university in the mid-Hudson region, SUNY, College at New Paltz offers over 50 undergraduate majors, ranging from business to communications to education to fine arts. New majors include environmental studies and entrepreneurship. The First-Year Internship Program allows freshmen to complete an internship during their second semester of college. There are more than 200 student organizations, and the campus is equipped with a planetarium and an art museum. About 40% of all new first-year and transfer students at New Paltz in Fall 2021 represent underrepresented demographic groups, including about 25% of incoming students who identify as Hispanic. About 95% of incoming students are from New York. New Paltz has a limited number of merit scholarships, and no additional application is required. The college offers the #YouAreWelcomeHere scholarship, which covers half of tuition for international students. After a decade-plus tenure as president, Donald P. Christian is set to retire in June 2022.

name: Presbyterian College
description: Presbyterian College is a small private school located in Clinton, SC, roughly halfway between Columbia and Greenville. There are 42 majors at Presbyterian, including pre-pharmacy Biology and Chemistry options, both of which send many students to Presbyterian’s School of Pharmacy. More than 40% of students are in Greek life, and Presbyterian’s fraternities and sororities are among the oldest in the country, dating back to 1890. Presbyterian awards a variety of scholarships, including the Alumni Referral and Legacy Scholarships, both of which are renewable $1,000 grants over four years. The Presbyterian Blue Hose compete in NCAA’s Division I. The unique Blue Hose nickname comes from the blue socks Presbyterian athletes wore in the early 1900s.

name: Texas Woman's University
description: Texas Woman’s University, located in Denton, TX, is one of the country’s largest universities primarily for women. Undergraduates can choose from 100 programs, and business and the health professions are the most popular areas of study. The university also has locations in Dallas and Houston. TWU has 10 institutes and centers and is an affiliate of the Texas Space Grant Consortium, which advances space research and technology. Students enjoy the academic and extracurricular benefits of being under an hour away from Dallas. The university is a Hispanic-Serving Institution, and more than half of students are from a diverse background. About 84% of alumni are working or continuing their education within a year of graduating.

name: Berklee College of Music
description: With a dedication to educating students on traditional and contemporary formats of music, Berklee College of Music in Boston, MA, is one of the nation’s most prestigious institutions for performing arts. The college offers 12 majors spanning many aspects of the music industry, from performance to composition to music production. Berklee has more than 350 ensemble and practice rooms on campus. Students also have opportunities to perform at a variety of venues at the school, including a 1,200-seat concert hall. About 40% of entering campus students receive institutional financial aid, covering an average of 40% of tuition. All entering students are automatically considered for merit scholarships, including one covering full tuition, housing, meal plan and fees for high achieving musicians with the financial need. More than 300 Grammy award winners call Berklee their alma mater, including big pop artists such as John Mayer and Charlie Puth.

name: Montclair State University
description: Located 12 miles outside of New York City in Montclair, NJ, Montclair State University is a public research institution that seeks to give students leadership and professional opportunities. Montclair State offers more than 100 majors. Business, psychology and programs in the performing arts are among the most popular areas of study. There are more than 120 student organizations on campus, including many recreational clubs, service orgs and about 40 Greek life chapters. Undergraduate students in STEM or education fields can participate in research programs at the university and outside internships. About 80% of students receive some form of financial aid. Incoming out-of-state freshmen may be eligible for a merit scholarship to have their tuition reduced to the same as in-state tuition. Departments in the College of Science and Mathematics also offer their own scholarships.

name: Dominican University of California
description: Dominican University of California, located in the San Francisco Bay Area, is a close-knit student body that has served the community for over 130 years. Students can choose from over 60 majors. Over half of students are enrolled in the School of Health and Natural Sciences. Students take part in community service through service-learning courses, completing more than 8,000 hours annually. Students are also required to complete a signature work—either research or a creative or scholarly project. The park-like campus is tranquil and cultivates an intimate community among its 1,000-plus student body, but students also have access to the big city-feel of San Francisco, which is just a half hour away. The student body is diverse, with about 68% identifying as a student of color. About one-third of students are Pell Grant-eligible, and 23% are first generation.

name: University of New Mexico
description: New Mexico’s flagship state school, the University of New Mexico is located in the heart of Albuquerque. UNM’s campus is situated on the traditional lands of the Pueblo people, and the university maintains in touch with its Native American roots, modeling the campus in the Pueblo Revival architectural style. 50% of students identify as Hispanic and 5% as Native American. The Kay Glantz Scholarship awards up to $2,000 to students that plan to teach on a Native Nation in New Mexico or the Navajo Nation. Student organizations run the gamut from Advancing Women In Science to Culinary Medicine Interest. The Greek Life community has over 20 men's and women's organizations. Notable UNM alumni include Gary Johnson, former New Mexico governor and Libertarian Party presidential candidate and Pro Football Hall of Famer Brian Urlacher.
carnegieClassification: Doctoral Universities: Very High Research Activity

name: Point Loma Nazarene University
description: Point Loma Nazarene University is a liberal arts college in San Diego, CA, affiliated with the Church of the Nazarene. The university believes in helping students reach their potential through spiritual growth, academic achievement and service. PLNU offers more than 60 undergraduate programs for students to pursue. Nursing, family sciences and business administration are among the most popular majors. About 91% of students received some form of financial aid. In the 2019-20 academic year, around 62% of incoming students received a merit scholarship. Students may earn a merit scholarship without submitting test scores. More than three-quarters of incoming freshmen join Alpha Groups, small faith and socializing organizations. PLNU holds men’s and women’s spiritual retreats away from the university several times a year. The university offers students the opportunity to serve in several Christian ministries in San Diego. There are also 11 NCAA Division II sports teams and 14 different club sports on campus.

name: Bennington College
description: Known for its emphasis on the arts, Bennington College is a private liberal arts gem in Vermont. Bennington does not have traditional dormitories, instead it primarily housing students in houses of 30-45 people, fostering a homey environment complete with fireplaces in common rooms. More than half of Bennington undergraduates major in the visual and performing arts. Other popular majors are in literature, music and dance. All Bennington students have internships related to their field of study, a majority of which take place during the six-week field work term between the fall and spring semesters. Emmy Award-winning “Game of Thrones” actor Peter Dinklage graduated from Bennington in 1991. His 2012 commencement speech in which he encouraged graduates to give themselves permission to fail was named by NPR as one of the best commencement speeches ever.

name: St. Catherine University
description: For St. Catherine University, a diverse student experience is key. The Catholic university in Minneapolis, MN, is designated as an Asian American and Native American Pacific Islander-serving Institution, and 35% come from multicultural backgrounds. Since St. Kate’s is a women’s college, 94% of students are women, though men can join graduate and associate’s programs. Regardless of their racial or gender identity, students at St. Catherine share a Minnesotan upbringing: around 75% are in-state students. Academically, Katies pursue ways to pay it forward; the most popular majors are nursing, public health and social work. St. Kate's St. Paul campus houses the O’Shaughnessy, which is integral to the Twin Cites arts community. About 200 of the school’s 3,491 study abroad every year across 150 programs in 50 countries. Katies have been invited to participate in the Mayo Innovation Scholars Program, an opportunity for undergraduates to engage in research projects developed by professionals, since 2009.

name: Ursinus College
description: About 27 miles northwest of Philadelphia in Collegeville, PA, Ursinus is a liberal arts college that encourages students to explore academic and professional opportunities. The 170-acre campus is home to many amenities, including an art museum and a sustainable farm. The college has three centers for student development, which focus on global service-learning, science and society and entrepreneurial pursuits. There are 34 majors for students to choose from, as well as five professional programs, 10 areas of specialization and 59 minors. Every first-year student must complete the “Common Intellectual Experience,” a two-semester course that fosters reading, writing and interpretive skills. About 99% of students receive some form of financial aid. Every first year applicant is automatically considered for merit scholarships of up to $40,000. Students take part in more than 100 clubs and organizations. Around 20% of students participate in the college’s eight sororities and five fraternities.

name: Oregon Institute of Technology
description: The Oregon Institute of Technology in Klamath Falls, OR, is a public polytechnic specializing in engineering, technology, health, business, communication and applied sciences. Students can choose from over 40 majors. Oregon Tech also offers programs in the Portland-Metro area, in Salem, OR and online. The university partners with industry leaders, like the National Energy Technology Laboratory, to give students an opportunity to conduct meaningful research. The Engineering Co-Op program allows students to engage in two six-month internships during their undergraduate career. Presidential Scholarships are merit awards that range from $2,000 to $4,000 for Oregon residents—nearly 80% of students hail from the state—and $6,000 to $10,000 for non-residents. Engineering students also qualify for an annual $1,000 scholarship. On average, 96% of Oregon Tech graduates are employed or enrolled in graduate school within six months of graduating.

name: Illinois Wesleyan University
description: Illinois Wesleyan University focuses on giving students a broad liberal arts education with opportunities to learn outside of the classroom. The campus spans 82 acres north of downtown Bloomington, mid-way between Chicago and St. Louis. There are 38 majors for students to choose from, as well as eight pre-professional programs. Nursing is the most popular major, closely followed by accounting. Students can choose to study a course outside the normal curriculum during a one-month May term in the classroom or abroad. There are around 120 clubs on campus, including nine fraternity and sorority chapters. About 71% of students complete an internship by the time they graduate. The university has a 91% first-year retention rate, and 95% of graduates are employed or attend graduate school within six months. More than 95% of students receive some form of financial aid, which covers over half of tuition on average. The university offers scholarships of up to $35,000 for fine arts majors and a scholarship package of at least $30,000 for students from McLean County.

name: California Lutheran University
description: California Lutheran University is a private institution in Thousand Oaks, CA, that is one of the few universities affiliated with the Evangelical Lutheran Church in America. Undergraduates can choose from over 40 majors. Popular programs include business administration, psychology and biology. Over half of students participate in an internship during their time at Cal Lutheran. Students can take part in around 100 student organizations. The campus ministry hosts a weekly chapel service and additional faith-based programming. Cal Lutheran has been designated a Hispanic-serving institution, and more than half of the undergraduate population identifies as non-white. Students can earn awards up to full-tuition through the Presidential, Steven Dorfman and Transfer Achievement Scholarships. Cal Lutheran also offers talent, legacy and faith-based scholarships.

name: Manhattanville College
description: Manhattanville College is a private liberal arts school in Purchase, NY, 22 miles north of Manhattan. It was founded in 1841 as the Academy of the Sacred Heart, a Catholic boarding school for women. Today it offers 45 undergraduate majors and minors and 75 graduate degrees. Students can also design their own majors. There are more than 45 clubs and organizations on campus and 100 study abroad opportunities. The Valiants compete in the NCAA’s Division III across 22 varsity teams.

name: Florida Agricultural and Mechanical University
description: Florida Agricultural and Mechanical University was founded in 1887 as the State Normal College for Colored Students. Today it is the only historically black public school in Florida, and its campus sits in the heart of the state capital, Tallahassee.Through a partnership with Florida Atlantic University, FAMU established a highly selective Medical Scholars Program, in which qualified incoming freshmen are conditionally guaranteed admission to FAU’s medical school after graduating from FAMU. The FAMU Rattlers compete at the Division I level and earned the Rattlers moniker when FAMU relocated its campus to a previously rattlesnake-infested location in 1891. Journalism is one of the most popular majors at FAMU, and many former students go on to work in the media and in entertainment, including longtime NFL reporter Pam Oliver and Grammy-winning rapper Common.

name: University of Wisconsin-Platteville
description: University of Wisconsin, Platteville is a public university with specializations in STEM and agriculture that prides itself on student-centered experiences. Undergraduates can choose from over 50 majors, as well as pre-professional and online programs. Popular programs include mechanical engineering, criminal justice and industrial technology management. The university also has two other campuses in Baraboo Sauk County and Richland. About 90% of students participate in at least one internship, co-op, or experiential learning experience before graduating. The highly competitive Chancellor’s Scholarship awards up to full tuition and fees, and students from diverse backgrounds are eligible for an annual $2,500 scholarship. The Pioneer Pledge guarantees that room and board is covered for incoming freshmen who are Wisconsin residents and are Pell Grant-eligible. Over 90% of graduates remain in the Midwest.

name: University of Scranton
description: The University of Scranton provides a Jesuit liberal arts education that stresses the values of justice and service. The 58-acre campus is located in downtown Scranton, PA, two hours from Philadelphia and New York City. The university offers 68 majors and ten concentration programs. The most popular programs are in health care fields, such as nursing and kinesiology. The university partners with local community organizations for students to participate in service. Students perform more than 170,000 hours of volunteer work every year. About 96% of students are offered university scholarships or need-based aid. Students are automatically considered for several merit scholarships. There are about 80 clubs on campus for students to join, including honor societies, spiritual groups and nonprofit organizations.

name: Loyola University New Orleans
description: Loyola University New Orleans provides students with a Jesuit approach to education, emphasizing critical thinking and hands-on experiences. Loyola offers over 40 undergraduate majors across five colleges, as well as online programs. The university is also home to a bachelor of science degree in hip-hop and R&B, the first of its kind in the country. Loyola launched its first January term, during which students can take classes between semesters, in 2021. Campus life is defined by service learning trips in New Orleans, Jamaica and South Africa, as well as retreats, faith communities and other student organizations, including Greek life. Freshmen are automatically considered for merit-based academic scholarships ranging from $14,000 to $23,000 per year. The university also provides awards for social justice, music and athletics. About 84% of graduates are employed or enrolled in graduate school within six months of graduation.

name: SUNY Polytechnic Institute
description: The State University of New York Polytechnic Institute (known as “SUNY Poly”) is a small, public university campuses outside of Utica and Albany, NY. SUNY Poly’s 400-acre campus outside of Utica houses four main residence halls and the schools of business, arts and sciences, engineering and health sciences. The school's second campus in Albany dedicated to nanoscale science and nanoscale engineering. Students at SUNY Poly can get a break from studying with Division 3 athletics, dozens of official student clubs and direct access to the foothills of the Adirondack Mountains. The annual Summer Undergraduate Research Program gives students the opportunity to pursue funded research opportunities with faculty members. SUNY Poly offers merit-based scholarships, as well as the Cree | Wolfspeed scholarship for students from disadvantaged backgrounds looking to pursue STEM education.

name: CUNY, John Jay College of Criminal Justice
description: As one of the first liberal arts colleges with a criminal-justice focus, the John Jay College of Criminal Justice in the City University of New York system prepares students for serving the public. John Jay offers 41 undergraduate majors — the most popular being criminal justice, forensic psychology and criminology — and 16 master’s programs across 24 departments and four programs. Students are also able to participate in research opportunities with faculty. The college serves a diverse population; it is classified as a Hispanic Serving Institution and a Minority Serving Institution, nearly 50% of students are first-generation, over 50% identify as Hispanic or African American and there are more than 500 veterans enrolled. John Jay also has the Prisoner Reentry Institute to support current and formerly incarcerated students. There are over 50 student organizations, many of which are cultural or academic, and no Greek life. John Jay is located in Midtown Manhattan, making it convenient for students to explore all that New York City has to offer. The majority of alumni go on to careers in government and nonprofit organizations, and 50% work in public service. Henry Lee, a forensic scientist who worked on the O. J. Simpson trial and the reinvestigation of the John F. Kennedy assassination, attended the college

name: Linfield University
description: Founded in 1858, Linfield College is a private liberal arts school in McMinnville, OR, that maintains loose ties to its founding Baptist Church. The school officially changed its name from Linfield College to Linfield University last year. Linfield has another campus in Portland, about an hour drive from the main campus. About a quarter of Linfield students receive Pell grants, while 94% of all incoming undergraduates receive some form of aid. Notable Linfield alumni include Amy Tan, author of The Joy Luck Club, and Scott Brosius, former World Series MVP.

name: Middle Tennessee State University
description: Middle Tennessee State University is a large public university in Murfreesboro, TN, that’s known for its music production program and affordable tuition. Students at MTSU can choose from more than 60 majors across 7 different colleges. The most popular programs are in business, visual and performing arts and communications. There are more than 350 student groups on campus for students to engage in. MTSU is home to the Department of Recording Industry, a leading music production program that trains students in audio production and songwriting. Graduates from the Recording Industry program have gone on to work with musicians including Keith Urban, Kacey Musgraves and Bruce Springsteen. First-time freshmen are eligible for merit scholarships based on GPA and standardized testing scores.

name: Fairfield University
description: Fairfield University offers a broad, Jesuit education at its campus near the coast of Fairfield, Connecticut. The campus is a five minute drive to the beach and an hour long drive to New York City. All undergraduate students complete the school’s “Magis Core Curriculum,” designed to engage students with an expanse of “disciplinary perspectives,” the school says. The university bills itself as “The Modern Jesuit Catholic University.” offers more than 100 student clubs and organizations on campus, including several community service organizations, club and intramural sports. All admitted students are automatically considered for merit scholarships ranging from $15,000 to $28,000. Fairfield also offers more than 170 endowed, need-based scholarships.

name: Hampden-Sydney College
description: Hampden-Sydney College in Hampden Sydney, VA, is one of the few remaining men’s colleges in the country. The private liberal arts college prides itself on providing a collaborative learning environment and sense of brotherhood. The college offers 27 majors for students to choose from. Students are required to complete the Rhetoric Program, a rigorous public speaking and analytical writing course sequence.  There are more than 60 clubs on campus, including some dozen academic groups and 10 fraternities. Many students participate in a variety of outdoor activities on Hampden-Sydney’s 1,300-acre campus near the Blue Ridge Mountains. All applicants are automatically considered for merit scholarships of up to $30,000. There is also a $20,000 per year scholarship for students who are eagle scouts, who make up about 10% of the student body.

name: The University of Tennessee-Chattanooga
description: A public school, the University of Tennessee, Chattanooga has scenic views of the Tennessee River and nearby mountains. About 20% of students major in the Gary W. Rollins College of Business. Other popular fields of study include education and nursing. UTC offers a variety of scholarships, such as the $2,000 per semester HOPE Scholarship that draws upon proceeds from the state lottery or the $5,000 per year Chancellor’s Scholarship for students that scored a 29 or higher on the ACT. With about one-third of students eligible for Pell Grants, three-quarters of students receive some form of financial assistance. Pro Football Hall of Famer Terrell Owens and “Saved by the Bell” actor Dennis Haskins are both UT Chattanooga alumni.

name: Central Michigan University
description: Central Michigan University in Mount Pleasant, MI, is a public research university with a large student body and a wide range of academic offerings. CMU offers more than 200 undergraduate programs, as well as accelerated and online programs. In addition to its main campus, the university has satellite locations across Michigan, the U.S. and in Canada. Exercise science, business and communications are popular programs. The university operates an island biological research station on Beaver Island, where students can lodge while they conduct research. Students can take part in over 400 student organizations, including Greek life and Division I sports. Merit awards cover from 20% to 65% of tuition for up to four years. Competitive awards include the Centralis Scholarship Program, which covers up to the cost of attendance. Over $300 million is awarded in scholarships and financial aid annually.

name: William Paterson University of New Jersey
South Dakota School of Mines and Technology
description: Originally founded in 1885 as a mining school, South Dakota School of Mines and Technology is the state’s modern leader in STEM education. More than three-quarters of students are engineers. South Dakota Mines’ campus is home to The Museum of Geology. Visitors to the museum can see mounted skeletons of dinosaurs, meteorites and rare fossils from the nearby White River Badlands. Located in the Rushmore Region, campus is 25 miles from Mount Rushmore National Memorial. Most South Dakota Mines alumni continue in engineering after graduation—the most popular employers of alumni are Kiewit, one of the largest American construction companies and Garmin, a worldwide leader in GPS technology.

name: Maine Maritime Academy
description: Maine Maritime Academy in Castine, ME, is a small public institution dedicated to producing officers and engineers for the U.S. Merchant Marine and other nautical leaders. All of MMA’s academic programs center around engineering, management, science, and transportation. Majors include marine systems engineering and vessels operations and technology. MMA students don’t need to venture far for amenities, as the Curtis Hall dormitory has its own barber shop, gaming lounge and computer lab. The MMA learning experience is unique: learning facilities include research vessels, marine science labs, power plant and navigation simulators and a liquid cargo system simulator. MMA ranks as one of the top schools in terms of time to recoup investment and 94% of students receive some form of financial assistance.

name: Emerson College
description: Located in the heart of Boston’s theater district, Emerson is a private college known for its communications and visual and performing arts programs. Undergraduates can choose from almost 30 majors. Students can engage with the vibrant art scene of Boston, as well as at Emerson’s campuses in Los Angeles and the Netherlands. The college owns more performance space than any other institution in Boston, including the Cutler Majestic Theatre. Student-run media include WERS 88.9 FM, the college’s award-winning radio station, and Ploughshares, one of the country’s most prestigious literary magazines. Alumni include scores of notable performers, including comedian Jay Leno and actor Henry Winkler.

name: Seattle Pacific University
description: Seattle Pacific University is a small, private Christian school in Seattle. Founded by the Free Methodist Church, SPU remains strongly religious, practicing a “historically orthodox” and ”clearly Evangelical” Christianity. A year after graduation, 93% of students were working, in graduate school, the military or a volunteer position. SPU is undertaking a drastic effort to become more affordable: the university announced a 25% decrease in tuition for the 2021-22 academic year. The school has attracted attention in 2021 for the board’s hiring policy that is allegedly discriminatory toward LGBTQ+ individuals, leading to a vote of no confidence from the faculty toward leadership. “Survivor” host Jeff Probst and In-N-Out Burger co-founder Esther Snyder both attended SPU.

name: Maryland Institute College of Art
description: The Maryland Institute College of Art in Baltimore, MD, is the oldest continuously degree-granting college of art and design in the country. Undergraduates can choose from 20 majors, including a five-year master of art education program. All students take core First Year Experience, a trans-disciplinary curriculum of inter-related courses addressing contemporary art and design practice. Students can also choose a studio concentration or a liberal arts minor. Facilities include 10 makerspaces and studios, including the Make Cool Stuff Lab, a makerspace with 3D printers, digital cutters and other technology geared for freshmen to accustom them to the fundamentals of digital fabrication. MICA has study abroad programs for fine art, design and media and humanistic studies, as well as summer travel intensives to London, Paris, South Korea, Venice, Sorrento and South Africa. Students take part in art-centric service projects in the Baltimore community and are part of special interest student organizations. Annually, the college administers more than $60 million in financial assistance to undergraduate students, and the MICA-funded scholarships and grant programs provide more than $31 million.
carnegieClassification: Special Focus Four-Year: Arts, Music & Design Schools

name: College of Wooster
description: Known for its commitment to research and its historic Scottish ties, the College of Wooster is a small private liberal arts school in Wooster, OH. All Wooster undergraduates participate in research, matching one-on-one with a faculty member for an Independent Study capstone project in their senior year. Wooster’s 21 Division III varsity sports teams compete as the Fighting Scots, an allusion to the school’s roots in the Presbyterian Church. The school’s Scottish affinity goes further than athletics: the Wooster Scottish Arts Society fields a Pipe Band and Highland Dancers, and offers “Scottish Arts” scholarships on an audition basis. Some 97% of Wooster graduates report gaining admission to their top-choice graduate school.

name: New Mexico State University
description: A large, public land-grant university in Las Cruces, NM, New Mexico State University is one of the state’s two public flagship institutions. Undergraduates at NMSU can choose from close to 100 majors, with extensive offerings in agriculture, animal sciences and environmental studies. The school also offers majors in a wide range of professional fields like hotel management. NMSU has extensive cultural and recreational offerings on campus, including art galleries, a theater and an 18-hole golf course. New Mexico residents that meet certain GPA and standardized testing thresholds are eligible for the President’s Associates Excellence scholarship, which provides full tuition. Notable NMSU graduates include former New Mexico Governor Garrey Carruthers and Starbucks CEO Kevin Johnson.

name: University of Puerto Rico, Mayaguez
description: The University of Puerto Rico-Mayaguez is the second largest university in the University of Puerto Rico system. In addition to being a land-grant university, the University of Puerto Rico-Mayaguez is part of the sea-grant and space-grant research consortia and is considered one of the best institutions to study tropical marine science. Students on the 315-acre tropical campus can participate in 100 different student organizations, as well as 16 men’s sports teams and 12 women’s sports teams, called the Tarzans and the Janes, respectively. Notable alumni include biological oceanographer Antonio Mignucci and NASA scientist and inventor Olga D. González-Sanabria.

name: Stetson University
description: Stetson University is a private school whose main campus is in DeLand, FL, located halfway between Daytona Beach and Orlando. Through the Roland George Investment Program, Stetson business students manage a real $5.5 million portfolio of bonds and stocks. More than a quarter of students major in a business field. The Stetson Hatters field 18 Division I varsity teams, with all sports competing in the ASUN Conference, except for football, which is a member of the Pioneer Football League. Some of Stetson’s most famous alumni played for the Hatters' baseball team: Cy Young Award winners Jacob deGrom and Corey Kluber both are Stetson alumni.

name: Sam Houston State University
description: Sam Houston State is a large, public research university in Huntsville, TX, that offers a traditional college experience as well as a number of flexible degree offerings. Undergraduates at SHSU can choose from more than 80 majors, with liberal arts and pre-professional offerings. Many majors, particularly from the school of criminal justice, are available online. Sam Houston State accommodates a wide variety of students. Around 45% of students are first generation college students, and 75% work while pursuing their degree. While a small minority of students live on campus, the school maintains an active atmosphere with a large number of student groups, Greek life and traditions like the Bearkat tailgate. Notable SHSU alumni include broadcast journalist Dan Rather, director Richard Linklater and St. Luke’s Health CEO Melinda Estes.

name: Stonehill College
description: Founded by the Congregation of Holy Cross in 1948, Stonehill College in Easton, MA, gives students a Catholic liberal arts education to mold them into global citizens valuing integrity and compassion. Stonehill College offers 52 undergraduate majors in the liberal arts, including a dual engineering degree in partnership with the University of Notre Dame and King’s College. Criminology and psychology are among the most popular majors. Students are able to join several dozen clubs at Stonehill, including pre-professional groups, 14 club sports and various volunteer programs. The college competes in 23 varsity NCAA Division II sports. About 80% of students join a sports or recreation activity. Every year, students donate nearly 100,000 hours of community service through campus and partner programs. “The Farm” at Stonehill has donated about 95,000 pounds of produce to community partners. Stonehill offers a variety of different scholarships, such as ones for students who attend certain Congregation of Holy Cross high schools in Massachusetts and a scholarship for multiple family members that attend the college.

name: Oakland University
description: A public research institution, Oakland University is located in Rochester MI, a Detroit suburb. OU’s on-campus Golf & Learning Center features two 18-hole golf courses, a driving range and three putting greens. Students receive a heavily discounted rate to golf. The Eye Research Institute Summer Undergraduate Program in Eye Research (SUPER) offers a unique opportunity for undergraduates to engage in ophthalmologic research. SUPER participants receive a research fellowship worth up to $4,250. 44% of students receive need-based financial aid and 75% of students receive some form of aid. 99% of employed OU graduates remain in Michigan.

name: California State University, San Bernardino
description: California State University, San Bernardino is a large public university. There were more than 19,000 students enrolled in Fall 2021, with the vast majority hailing from San Bernardino and Riverside counties. Eighty percent of students are first generation college students. The university is also a Hispanic Serving Institution. Students can choose from more than 70 academic programs, including a bachelor of science in computer engineering and a bachelor of arts in social work. The university’s Santos Manuel Student Union buildings offer a range of opportunities, including a bowling alley, gamers lounge, as well as a career center and the university’s Undocumented Student Success Center.

name: Rowan University
description: Rowan University is a public research institution in Glassboro, New Jersey. In Fall 2022, more than 19,000 students were enrolled across undergraduate, graduate, medical and professional levels. The university, which traces its founding back to 1923, says it will become “a new model for higher education” because of its emphasis on agility, inclusivity and responsiveness. The university offers 90 bachelor’s programs, in addition to master’s, professional and doctoral degrees. The university has a planetarium and a fossil park. The university’s namesake, Henry Rowan, is honored with a statue on campus. The college of engineering is also named for Henry Rowan, the industrialist who, along with his wife Betty, donated $100 million to the school in 1992.

name: Saint Cloud State University
description: An hour west of Minneapolis, St. Cloud State University is a large, hockey-focused public school in St. Cloud, MN. St. Cloud State’s campus is 100 acres and located along the Mississippi River. Spread across eight schools and colleges, there are more than 200 academic programs at the university. The most popular fields of study include communications, business administration and finance. St. Cloud State University is part of a nationwide effort to re-imagine the first-year experience aimed at ensuring success for all students, particularly low income, first generation and students of color. The St. Cloud State Huskies compete in the Division II Northern Sun Intercollegiate Conference in 16 of 18 sports, but the Huskies’ men’s and women’s ice hockey teams are Division I powerhouses. The men’s hockey team lost in the 2021 national championship game.

name: University of Dallas
description: With an undergraduate enrollment of 1,400, the University of Dallas provides a tight-knit Catholic liberal arts education that is accepting of all faiths. The campus is about ten miles from downtown Dallas. The university offers 25 areas of study, as well as many non-major concentrations. The core curriculum consists of 19 courses in English, theology, natural sciences, social sciences and foreign languages. Students can choose to study abroad in modern language or science programs. Many students also participate in UD’s Rome semester programs. All incoming freshmen are automatically considered for merit scholarships ranging from $15,000 to $30,000 annually. There is also a scholarship for students who attend Catholic high schools in the Dallas-Fort Worth area. There are around 45 clubs and organizations for students to join, including science and humanities clubs, advocacy groups and nine sports and recreation clubs.

name: University of Memphis
description: The University of Memphis is a large public research university in Tennessee’s second-largest city. Campus is a 15-minute drive from Downtown Memphis and a mile from the Memphis Botanic Garden. Memphis was awarded $50.2 million in research funding last year, marking a record for the school and a 23.2% increase from the year prior. FedEx is headquartered near campus in Memphis, and the company sponsors the university’s FedEx Institute of Technology, Memphis’ hub for emerging technology research.  Some of Memphis’ most famous alumni once suited up for the school’s athletic teams, including Pro Football Hall of Famer Isaac Bruce and former NBA MVP Derrick Rose.
carnegieClassification: Doctoral Universities: Very High Research Activity

name: Washington & Jefferson College
description: Spanning a 65-acre campus 30 miles south of Pittsburg in Washington, PA, Washington & Jefferson College is a liberal arts college known for its long history—dating back to its founding in 1781. The college offers 33 undergraduate majors, 16 major emphases, and four pre-professional programs. Business, psychology and political science are the most popular majors. In January between the fall and spring semesters, the college holds JayTerm, a time when students complete an interdisciplinary course outside of normal curriculum and have an opportunity to study abroad or fulfill a professional experience. About 99% of students receive some form of financial aid. The average institutional aid for incoming freshmen is approximately $30,000. Through the Magellan Project, W&J provides funding to students to study abroad, fulfill an internship or complete research.

name: New York Institute of Technology
description: A midsize private university with campuses in Manhattan and Old Westbury, NY, the New York Institute of Technology provides its students with a STEM education that emphasizes career readiness. NYIT offers undergraduate students 41 majors across 6 different colleges. The most popular programs are in engineering, IT and architecture. Within 6 months of graduating, 94% of NYIT graduates found work or were furthering their education. The school’s Computer Graphics Lab helped pioneer some of the 20th century’s biggest advancements in computer animation, and boasts founders and key artists at Pixar, Disney and Dreamworks among its alumni. Notable NYIT alumni include Univision CEO Vincent Sadusky and Argus Cybersecurity’s North American president LaVern Rhaburn Sula.

name: Dordt University
description: Dordt University in Sioux Center, IA, integrates the Christian faith into its teachings for students to carry on in their lives. Dordt has 40 undergraduate programs — including Christianity and Popular Culture, and theology — 12 preprofessional programs and graduate education programs. The top majors include education, business, engineering, agriculture and nursing. In May 2019, Dordt officially transitioned from a college to a university. Students are actively involved on campus; about 75% participate in clubs and over half attend chapel, although it is not mandatory. About 84% of students live on campus, and in 2018 more than half hailed from places farther than 500 miles away from campus. Dordt offers numerous study-abroad programs, and students often participate in mission-service trips over breaks. Within six months of graduation, 99 percent of students are either employed or in graduate school.

name: North Carolina A&T State University
description: The largest HBCU in the country, STEM-focused North Carolina A&T State University is in Greensboro, NC. NC A&T is the top producer of Black engineering graduates, and 13% of students are engineers.There are 54 undergraduate degree programs. The university has recently seen a rise in donations, receiving $88 million in donations last fiscal year, including a $45 million gift from MacKenzie Scott. The 2021 NC A&T freshman class includes a unique member: 35-year-old former NBA star J.R. Smith is joining the school’s men’s golf team. Politician, minister and activist Jesse Jackson graduated from NC A&T, where he was quarterback for the football team, student body president and civil rights leader.

name: University of Florida, Online
description: The University of Florida-Online is the virtual arm of the University of Florida, providing online education to undergraduates who choose not to enroll on campus. The university offers 25 programs in disciplines such as geography, environmental management and sports management. Tuition for online students is about half of what it costs to attend the University of Florida, and students are also eligible to receive financial aid.

name: SUNY at Purchase College
description: The artsiest member of the State University of New York system, SUNY at Purchase College is 30 miles north of New York City in Purchase, NY. There are 47 majors at Purchase, many of which center around the arts, such as Acting, Studio Production and Voice and Opera Studies. Purchase’s 500-acre campus almost exclusively features buildings of the same shade of light brick, metaphorically meant to emphasize that Purchase’s color comes from within. More than 40% of students major in the visual and performing arts. Purchase is a breeding ground for the biggest names in Hollywood, as actors Edie Falco, Wesley Snipes and Stanley Tucci are all alumni of the school.

name: St. Edward's University
description: St. Edward’s University is a private institution founded by the Congregation of Holy Cross in Austin, TX. Undergraduates can choose from over 50 majors, including pre-professional programs, as well as partner programs with other universities like Washington University in St. Louis. Popular programs include psychology, biology and business administration. Approximately 90% of students engage in experiential learning before they graduate, and the university has 20 global partners for students to study abroad at. Merit scholarships for freshmen range from $14,000 to $26,000 annually. In 2020–2021, 83% of freshmen received merit scholarships. The Moreau Scholarship awards full tuition for a student who graduated from a Holy Cross high school. The university has produced 75 Fulbright Award winners since 2008.

name: Massachusetts Maritime Academy
description: The Massachusetts Maritime Academy is a public college in Buzzards Bay, MA, originally established in 1891 to graduate Merchant Marine deck and engineering officers. The academy offers undergraduate programs in engineering, marine science, emergency management and transportation and business. Marine engineering is the most popular program. Many cadets are required to complete four “Sea Terms,” six-week voyages where cadets gain hands-on experience on the USTS Kennedy. About 10% of graduates from MMA pursue military service. There are a variety of clubs that cadets can join, including the Seventh Company regimental band, honor guard and drill team. Many freshmen compete in intramural sports for the Commandant’s Cup to build camaraderie within their company

name: SUNY, College of Environmental Science and Forestry
description: As the nation’s first college dedicated to environmental sustainability, SUNY College of Environmental Science and Forestry in Syracuse, NY, lives up to its name with education and research opportunities in the field. Many undergraduate students conduct research in fields from bioenergy to wildlife disease prevention. There are 23 majors for students to choose from, including aquatic and fisheries science, paper engineering, and conservation biology. SUNY-ESF offers several merit scholarships, including National Hispanic Scholarships, transfer student scholarships, and the Haudenosaunee Scholar Award for members of a Haudenosaunee nation. Due to its proximity to Syracuse University, SUNY-ESF students are able to take courses, join clubs and use the facilities at the university.

name: Willamette University
description: The oldest university in the Western United States, Willamette University in Salem, OR, is a leader in hands-on educational experiences. Willamette offers about 40 undergraduate majors, as well as dual degree programs in engineering, forestry, data science and business. In June 2021, the university completed a merger with the Pacific Northwest College of Art, the Northwest’s oldest school of art and design. About half of students study abroad. Tokyo International University and Willamette have been sister universities for over 50 years, allowing for unique exposure to Japanese culture. Willamette offers merit scholarships up to $20,000 per year, as well as scholarships for incoming students committed to music, theater, art, STEM, public health and environmental science. The university boasts 27 governors, senators and representatives, 11 Oregon Supreme Court justices and one Nobel Prize winner among its alumni.

name: University of Missouri, Saint Louis
description: Spread across 470 acres in suburban St. Louis county, the University of Missouri, St. Louis is the state’s largest public research university. Undergraduates can choose from over 80 degree programs, the most popular of which are in business, health and social sciences. UMSL also offers a number of online and evening degrees. The university has over 20 centers and institutes. Undergraduates are encouraged to take part in research, which they can present to state lawmakers at the annual Undergraduate Research Day. Incoming freshmen are automatically considered for scholarships ranging from $2,000 to $6,000 annually. UMSL offers 25 programs through the Fast Track Workforce Incentive Grant, which covers tuition and fees for Missouri residents ages 25 or older who are pursuing a degree in an in-demand discipline. More than 94% of UMSL’s graduates are employed, volunteering or continuing in higher education post-graduation, and about three-quarters of graduates remain in Missouri.

name: University of St. Thomas (TX)
description: The University of St. Thomas in Houston, TX blends the Catholic faith with a comprehensive educational experience. Undergraduate students can choose from nearly 40 majors, including STEM, nursing, education and premed. UST also offers 24 graduate degrees. UST’s core curriculum exposes students to a range of disciplines from mathematics to theology.  About 65% of freshmen practice the Catholic faith; the chapel hosts mass every day. Beyond the academic, honor and faith-based clubs, students can also take part in recreational trips throughout Texas, like horseback riding and wakeboarding, or campus ministry retreats. The Celts are provisional members in the NCAA Division III and accepted membership in the Southern Collegiate Athletic Conference. The university also prides itself on its diversity; about 68% of the student body are nonwhite, and 58 other countries are represented. UST’s business office offers a 0% interest monthly payment plan for tuition, and more than 96% of full-time freshmen receive a scholarship.

name: Marist College
description: Founded by the Marist Brothers, Marist College is a private liberal arts college in Poughkeepsie, NY, with a tight knit, active community. The college offers over 40 undergraduate majors, as well as dual degree programs. Popular areas of study include business, communications and psychology. In addition to its New York location, Marist also has a campus in Florence, Italy, the only four-year U.S. bachelor's degree program in the city. Over 700 students take part in athletics at Maristl. Campus life is elevated by over 80 student organizations, Greek life and beautiful views of the Hudson River. Marist awards academic scholarships ranging from $5,000 to $25,000 annually. Over the last five years, 97% of graduates were employed or in graduate school within six months of commencement. Marist alumni include 15 Fulbright Scholars and three Goldwater Scholars.

name: University of Wisconsin, La Crosse
description: Part of the University of Wisconsin system, the University of Wisconsin, La Crosse is known for its biology and beer. Biology is the most popular major at UW-La Crosse, and biology students can choose from a variety of unique academic concentrations, such as aquatic science, biomedical science and plant and fungal biology. Of the 45 undergraduate fields of study, other popular programs include healthy and physical education and finance. This fall will mark La Crosse’s 60th Oktoberfest, one of the largest Oktoberfest celebrations in the U.S. UW-La Crosse students stay active—87% of students participate in intramural sports. Chef and television personality Sandra Lee and Green Bay Packers general manager Brian Gutekunst are both UW-La Crosse alumni.

name: Goucher College
description: Goucher College is a liberal arts institution in Baltimore, MD, that strives to give every student a globalized education. The college requires all students who entered as a first-year student to complete a study abroad program. There are 30 majors at the college. During their final year, undergraduates must complete a capstone class or a project within their major. Through this process, students are encouraged to develop a portfolio to showcase in a symposium. There are more than 60 student clubs on campus, such as religious organizations, service groups, and unique clubs such as the Historic European Martial Arts Club. Goucher holds many traditions on campus, such as Get Into Goucher day and a spring celebration for academic achievement and the arts. Students can also take advantage of several networking opportunities, such as Coffee Chats with alumni. In the 2019-20 academic year, 97% of students received financial aid and applicants are automatically considered for merit scholarships of up to $35,000.

name: Augustana College
description: Augustana College in Rock Island, IL, is a liberal arts college that focuses on mentorship with advisors and exploration through professional opportunities. The college offers around 80 majors and pre-professional programs. Biology is by far the most populous major. Topics in business and psychology are also popular programs. Students have the opportunity to pursue research across any discipline in the field, a classroom, or a lab. Students are also encouraged to study abroad or complete an internship. Each year, the college gives the Augie Choice, a $2,000 fund, to around 550 students to complete one of these opportunities. For the class of 2019, 98% of graduates reported being employed or enrolled in graduate school within six months of commencement. There are around 200 clubs at the college for students to take part in, including 15 Greek life organizations.

name: Fairleigh Dickinson University-Florham Campus
description: Fairleigh Dickinson University’s Florham Campus in Morris County, New Jersey, is one of four campuses that operate under the FDU system. FDU Florham offers more than 60 undergraduate majors, with popular areas of study in psychology, business and communications. Fairleigh Dickinson offered more than $70 million worth of financial aid last year and 94% of full-time freshmen received some form of assistance. Florham’s 178 acre campus once belonged to socialite Florence Vanderbilt and her husband Hamilton Twombly. The university noted that the name Florham was derived from both their first names. Since 1958, FDU has owned and operated the campus, which remains primarily residential and houses nearly 1600 undergraduate and graduate students. Eighty percent of all freshmen stay on campus. The university boasts a thriving student life that includes fraternities and sororities, as well as a number of clubs and organizations; students must maintain at least a 2.0 grade point average to participate in clubs, a 2.3 GPA to hold a major office, and a 2.5 GPA to join Greek Life chapters. The FDU Florham Devils compete in the Middle Atlantic Freedom conference at the Division III level. Former basketball coach and ESPN College basketball analyst Seth Greenberg is one of many notable alumni to stem from Fairleigh Dickinson University.

name: Duquesne University
description: Duquesne University in Pittsburgh, PA is the only Spiritan Catholic institution of higher education in the United States. Undergraduates can choose from about 80 majors across eight colleges, as well as pre-med and pre-law programs and combined degree programs. Duquesne also has campuses in Rome and Dublin. The Undergraduate Research and Scholarship Symposium is held each spring and encourages undergraduates from all areas of study to engage in research. There are more than 250 student organizations at Duquesne, and numerous cultural and nightlight opportunities in Pittsburgh. About 8,000 Duquesne students, faculty and staff participate in volunteer activities annually. DU offers merit scholarships based on high school GPA, ranging up to $18,500. Other scholarship programs include the “Spirit of Community” Scholarship for students passionate about civic engagement and the National Hispanic Recognition Scholarship, a full-tuition award for the highest-ranked National Hispanic Scholar.

name: Saint Michael's College
description: The only Edmundite college in the world, Saint Michael’s College in Colchester, VT, is a private liberal arts college that emphasizes experiential learning. Students can choose from over 40 majors, as well as dual degree programs with other colleges, like Clarkson University and the University of Vermont. Popular programs include business administration, psychology and biology. In line with its Catholic roots, approximately 70% of students volunteer during their education. Additionally, more than a third of students study abroad. About 90% of students receive financial aid and all students are considered for merit awards, including the “Purple & Gold” Scholarships, which range from $17,000 to $30,000 annually. Nomination is required for the Book Award and the Presidential Scholarship, the latter of which is for Vermont students. Saint Michael’s has a 95% placement rate for full-time employment or graduate school. About 5% of alumni partake in full-time service programs.

name: Rollins College
description: Rollins College is a private liberal arts school in Winter Park, FL with a country club-esque campus where students take advantage of personalized majors to fit their individual goals. The campus is located on Lake Virginia, complete with a lakeside swimming pool with lounge chairs and a dozen tennis courts. Rollins prides itself on offering “cool classes,” with unique course topics includings children book writing, the history of piracy and sports analytics. Each spring on a day that is “too pretty to have class,” Rollins celebrates Fox Day by cancelling classes, allowing students to fully enjoy the picturesque campus. Fred Rogers, beloved host of “Mr. Rogers Neighborhood,” is a Rollins alumnus. This October, Rollins will unveil a 7-foot, 3,000-pound statue of Mr. Rogers.

name: Agnes Scott College
description: Located outside of Atlanta, GA, Agnes Scott College is an innovative women’s college with an experiential learning-based liberal arts core. The college offers close to 40 undergraduate majors, as well as programs in pre-health and pre-law. Psychology, biology and neuroscience are among the popular programs. Agnes Scott is part of the Atlanta Regional Council for Higher Education institution, allowing students to cross-register at any of the 18 other member colleges. Students take advantage of hands-on experiences at Agnes Scott; all first-year students engage in global immersion as part of the lliberal arts curriculum, and about half study abroad again. On average, 70% of students complete an internship and 36% are involved in research. The tight-knit community comes together through its 60 student organizations and wealth of traditions, including the sophomore ring ceremony. More than 80% of students are involved in community service. As a women’s college, Agnes Scott admits students who were assigned female at birth, as well as those who were assigned male or female at birth but who now identify as female, transgender, agender, gender fluid or non-binary. New for Fall 2022, all incoming students will receive the Agnes Assurance Scholarship, worth $22,000 annually, or a merit scholarship in a higher amount up to $26,000 annually. The college also offers awards covering the cost of attendance through Presidential Scholarships, and for Hispanic students through the Goizueta Scholarship.

name: Allegheny College
description: Allegheny College in Meadville, PA, is a private liberal arts college that encourages a well-rounded education for students. The college offers over 30 undergraduate majors, as well as pre-professional programs in health and law. Students can take dual degree courses with other colleges, like Case Western Reserve University and Chatham University. Popular programs include economics, environmental science and biology. Outside of the classroom, students take part in some of the more than 100 clubs, complete over 25,000 hours of community service annually and take part in undergraduate research. The Trustee Scholarship is the most prestigious award at the college, gifting up to $38,000 annually. The Top 10% Admission Program grants automatic admission to students from western Pennsylvania who graduate in the 10% of their class. Within eight months of graduation, over 90% of graduates are employed or continuing their education. Top industries include finance, healthcare, advanced manufacturing, government, non-profit work and education.

name: Northwood University
carnegieClassification: Special Focus Four-Year: Business & Management Schools

name: Berea College
description: Berea College, located in Berea, KY, guarantees that no student at the college has to pay tuition through awarding a Tuition Promise Scholarship valued at almost $200,000 over four years. Students at Berea are expected to participate in the work program at the college, where they work at least 10 hours per week throughout each regular term. Out of 44 undergraduate fields of study, including the popular biology, computer science and industrial production technologies, there is an option to create a custom major. About 93% of the class of 2019 graduates had studied abroad, fulfilled a paid internship, completed a service-learning course or participated in faculty-led research by the time they graduated. Berea College has a number of performing arts clubs, including music and theatre groups. There are also several campus publications and many multicultural organizations.

name: Louisiana Tech University
description: Louisiana Tech University is a STEM-focused public research institution in Ruston, LA, a college town in the northwest part of the state. Louisiana Tech does have a College of Liberal Arts, though STEM programs still dominate its academic scene. Biology, computer science and mechanical engineering are the most popular majors. The Thingery is a makerspace located on campus and offers workshops on topics from 3D modeling to animation. Each spring, Louisiana Tech hosts a new venture competition, with the top student entrepreneur teams earning the title of TOP DOG.
